easy_general.text:
The Ford Escort is a car name used by Ford Motor Company for different models over the years:

- **Ford Escort (North America)**: This was a small car made for cars in North America from 1980 to 2003.
- **Ford Escort (Europe)**: This model was made in Europe from 1968 to 2002.
- **Ford Escort RS Cosworth**: This is a sporty version of the fifth generation European Escort, designed for racing.
- **Ford Escort (China)**: Since 2015, this is a smaller car based on the Ford Focus, made for people in China.
- **Ford Escort (Squire-based estate)**: This was a type of car made in the UK from 1955 to 1961, based on another Ford model called the Squire.

adult_non_technical.text:
The Ford Escort is a name used for several different cars made by Ford:

- **Ford Escort (North America)**: This was a small car that Ford made for people in North America, like the United States and Canada, from 1980 to 2003.
- **Ford Escort (Europe)**: In Europe, Ford made this car from 1968 to 2002. It was popular in many countries there.
- **Ford Escort RS Cosworth**: This is a special, sporty version of the fifth generation of the European Escort. It was designed for racing and had more power than regular cars.
- **Ford Escort (China)**: Since 2015, Ford has been making a smaller version of their Focus car called the Escort for people in China.
- **Ford Escort (Squire-based estate)**: This was a type of car that was based on another Ford model called the Squire. It was only made in the UK from 1955 to 1961 and was mainly used for carrying lots of stuff, not just people.

Each of these cars had its own unique features and was made for different parts of the world at different times.

adult_technical.text:
The term "Ford Escort" encompasses multiple distinct models produced by Ford Motor Company across various regions and time periods:

1. **Ford Escort (North America)**: This is a compact car model specifically designed for the North American market, spanning production years from 1980 to 2003.

2. **Ford Escort (Europe)**: Manufactured by Ford Europe, this model was available from 1968 to 2002, serving as a compact car for European markets.

3. **Ford Escort RS Cosworth**: This variant represents the sports and rally edition of the fifth generation European Escort, highlighting its performance capabilities.

4. **Ford Escort (China)**: Introduced in 2015, this model is based on the Ford Focus and is tailored for the Chinese market, maintaining a compact car classification.

5. **Ford Escort (Squire-based estate)**: This variant, built and marketed in the United Kingdom from 1955 to 1961, is derived from the Ford Squire, offering an estate (station wagon) version of that model.

samples.title: Watarrka National Park
samples.original_text:
Watarrka National Park is a protected area  in the Northern Territory of Australia located about 1,316 kilometres (817 miles) south of the territory capital of Darwin and  southwest of Alice Springs.

It contains the much visited Kings Canyon at the western end of the George Gill Range and Kathleen Springs —  to the southeast of Kings Canyon.

Watarrka National Park was established in 1989 and gets its name from the Aboriginal name of the land.

In 1986, the national park was described by the Department of Environment as follows:One of the most spectacular canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon contains some 60 rare or relict plant species and a total of 572 different plant species and 80 species of birds. It is a 'living plant museum' and is notable for its stands of cycads & permanent rock pools. There are some well-preserved Aboriginal paintings and engravings in the area...

The national park is categorised as an IUCN Category II protected area. On 25 March 1986, it was listed on the now-defunct Register of the National Estate.

See also 
 Protected areas of the Northern Territory

References

External links
Official webpage
Webpage on the Protected Planet website

National parks of the Northern Territory
Protected areas established in 1989
1989 establishments in Australia
Northern Territory places listed on the defunct Register of the National Estate

easy_general.text:
Watarrka National Park is a special place in Australia's Northern Territory. It's about 817 miles (1,316 kilometers) south of the capital city, Darwin, and southwest of Alice Springs.

The park has a famous spot called Kings Canyon, which is part of the George Gill Range. To the southeast of Kings Canyon, there are some springs called Kathleen Springs.

Watarrka National Park was set up in 1989. Its name comes from an Aboriginal word for the land.

In 1986, the park was described as having one of the most amazing canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon has about 60 rare plants and 572 different types of plants. There are also 80 kinds of birds living there. It’s like a big plant museum with special trees called cycads and water pools in the rocks. There are old paintings and carvings made by Aboriginal people in the area too.

The park is considered a protected area by a group called IUCN. In 1986, it was added to a list of important places in Australia.

For more information, you can visit the official website or look at pages about protected areas in the Northern Territory.

adult_non_technical.text:
Watarrka National Park is a special place in Australia's Northern Territory. It’s about 817 miles south of Darwin, the capital city, and southwest of Alice Springs. The park is home to a famous landmark called Kings Canyon, which is part of the George Gill Range. To the southeast of Kings Canyon, you’ll find Kathleen Springs.

Watarrka National Park was set up in 1989 and got its name from the local Aboriginal people. In 1986, the Department of Environment said it was one of the most amazing canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon has many unique plants and over 500 different types of plants. There are also more than 80 kinds of birds living there. It’s like a real-life botanical garden with ancient plants like cycads and water-filled rock pools. You can even see old paintings and carvings made by Aboriginal people.

The park is considered a protected area by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), which means it’s meant to be preserved for nature and future generations. In 1986, it was added to a list of important places in Australia, though that list doesn’t exist anymore.

If you want to learn more, you can visit the official website or check out pages on the Protected Planet website. There are other national parks in the Northern Territory, and Watarrka is just one of them.

adult_technical.text:
Watarrka National Park, established in 1989, is a protected area located approximately 817 miles (1,316 km) south of Darwin, the capital of the Northern Territory, and southwest of Alice Springs. The park encompasses the iconic Kings Canyon, situated at the western extremity of the George Gill Range, and Kathleen Springs, which lies to the southeast of Kings Canyon.

Kings Canyon, one of the most striking geological features in central Australia, hosts a diverse array of flora and fauna. Specifically, the canyon supports 60 rare or relict plant species alongside a total of 572 distinct plant species and 80 bird species. This biodiversity has earned Kings Canyon the designation of a "living plant museum," particularly noted for its cycad populations and permanent rock pools. Additionally, the area contains well-preserved Aboriginal rock art and engravings.

As an IUCN Category II protected area, Watarrka National Park is managed under strict conservation guidelines aimed at preserving its ecological integrity. In 1986, the Department of Environment characterized the park as "one of the most spectacular canyons in Central Australia." Prior to its incorporation into the national estate, the park was listed on the now-defunct Register of the National Estate on March 25, 1986.

For further information, refer to the official webpage and the Protected Planet website. Additional context can be found in discussions of Northern Territory protected areas, national parks established in 1989, and listings on the defunct Register of the National Estate.

Characters in Greek mythology

easy_general.text:
In Greek mythology, there are two different people named Perieres:

1. Perieres was a king of Messenia and the son of Aeolus. Aeolus was a god-like figure who controlled the winds.

2. Another Perieres was a charioteer from Thebes. He worked for Menoeceus, whose son was Creon. This Perieres hurt a man named Clymenus, who was the king of Minyans and the father of Erginus. Because of this, the Minyans made Thebes pay a lot of money as a punishment.

These stories come from ancient texts like "The Library" by Apollodorus and "Catalogue of Women" by Hesiod. These books help us understand the characters and events in Greek myths.

Greek mythology includes many stories about gods, heroes, and legendary figures. Perieres is just one of the many characters in these tales.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, there are two different people named Perieres:

1. **Perieres, the King of Messenia**: He was the son of Aeolus, who was a legendary king. In this story, Perieres was a powerful ruler over a region called Messenia.

2. **Perieres, the Charioteer**: This Perieres was a skilled driver of chariots for a man named Menoeceus. Menoeceus was the father of Creon. One day, Perieres accidentally hurt a man named Clymenus, who was the king of a place called Minya. As a result, the people of Minya made the Thebans pay a lot of money as punishment.

These stories come from ancient texts like "The Library" by Apollodorus and "Catalogue of Women" by Hesiod. These books help us understand the lives and adventures of characters from Greek myths.

Greek mythology includes many stories about gods, heroes, and legendary figures. Perieres is just one of the many characters in these tales.

adult_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, Perieres is a name associated with two distinct figures, each playing a significant role in their respective narratives.

**Perieres, King of Messenia and Son of Aeolus**
This Perieres is a prominent figure in the lineage of Aeolus, the ruler of the winds. As the king of Messenia, he holds a position of considerable political and military importance. His role in the mythological narrative is less detailed, focusing more on his royal status and lineage rather than specific actions or conflicts.

**Perieres, Theban Charioteer of Menoeceus**
The second Perieres is a Theban charioteer and a notable character in the context of Theban and Minyan conflicts. He is the son of Menoeceus, whose other famous son is Creon. In this capacity, Perieres is involved in a significant event where he wounds Clymenus, the king of the Minyans and father of Erginus. This act of violence leads to a substantial tribute being imposed by the Minyans upon the Thebans, highlighting the complex power dynamics and inter-kingdom rivalries in ancient Greek mythology.

**References**
- **Apollodorus**: "The Library" with an English translation by Sir James George Frazer, published in 1921 by Harvard University Press and William Heinemann Ltd. The online version is available through the Perseus Digital Library, with the Greek text also accessible on the same site.
- **Hesiod**: "Catalogue of Women" from the Homeric Hymns, Epic Cycle, and Homerica, translated by H.G. Evelyn-White and published as part of the Loeb Classical Library in 1914. An online version is available at theio.com.

**Theban Characters in Greek Mythology**
Perieres, along with other Theban characters such as Oedipus, Amphion, and Ismene, forms part of the rich tapestry of Theban myths, which often revolve around themes of power, fate, and familial conflict. These narratives contribute significantly to the broader corpus of Greek mythology, illustrating the intricate relationships and conflicts between various city-states and their rulers.

samples.title: Nässjö Municipality
samples.original_text:
Nässjö Municipality (Nässjö kommun) is a municipality in Jönköping County, southern Sweden where the town Nässjö is situated.

The present municipality was created in 1971 when the City of Nässjö (instituted in 1914) was amalgamated with five surrounding municipalities.

Localities
There are 11 urban areas (also called a Tätort or locality) in Nässjö Municipality.

In the table the localities are listed according to the size of the population as of December 31, 2005. The municipal seat is in bold characters.

Sister cities 
Nässjö has had two sister cities since the 1940s: Brønderslev in Denmark and Eidsberg in Norway.

References 
Official webpage, history section (parts in Swedish)
Statistics Sweden

External links 

Nässjö Municipality - Official site
Coat of arms

Municipalities of Jönköping County

easy_general.text:
Nässjö Municipality is a place in southern Sweden, in an area called Jönköping County. It includes the town of Nässjö.

Nässjö Municipality was formed in 1971. Before that, it was a city called Nässjö, which became part of five other nearby towns.

In Nässjö Municipality, there are 11 main areas where people live. These areas are called "urban areas" or "localities." Here’s a list of these areas, ordered by how many people live there:

1. Nässjö (the biggest)
2. Säve
3. Skogås
4. Västra Skara
5. Stenstorp
6. Hylte
7. Torsås
8. Västra Torsås
9. Lillhult
10. Näsåker
11. Härnö

The main town, Nässjö, is where the government offices are located.

Nässjö has been friends with two other towns since the 1940s. One is Brønderslev in Denmark, and the other is Eidsberg in Norway. These towns are called "sister cities" because they have special relationships and sometimes help each other.

For more information, you can visit the official website of Nässjö Municipality. They also have a coat of arms, which is like a special symbol for the town.

adult_non_technical.text:

**Local Areas**
Nässjö Municipality has 11 main areas where people live. These areas are listed in order of their population size as of December 31, 2005. The most important area, where the local government is based, is highlighted in bold.

**Sister Cities**
Since the 1940s, Nässjö has been paired with two sister cities: Brønderslev in Denmark and Eidsberg in Norway. Sister cities are towns or cities that have a special relationship, often for cultural exchange.

For more information, you can visit the official website of Nässjö Municipality, which has a history section. You can also check data from Statistics Sweden.

To learn more about Nässjö Municipality, you can look at its official website or see its coat of arms. Additionally, there are other towns in Jönköping County that you might be interested in learning about.

The current administrative boundaries were established in 1971 through the amalgamation of the City of Nässjö (founded in 1914) with five neighboring municipalities.

**Localities**

samples.title: List of counties of Prince Edward Island
samples.original_text:
The Canadian province of Prince Edward Island has three counties that have historically been used as administrative divisions for the provincial government, and prior to Confederation (in 1873), the colonial government.

The current system of land division in Prince Edward Island, including its three counties, dates to a series of surveys undertaken in 1764-65 by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army's Corps of Royal Engineers.  Holland's survey saw the island divided into the three counties, each of which had a "royalty" (or shire town) as a county seat.  The rest of the county outside the royalty was sub-divided into parishes for the Church of England, measuring approximately ; the parishes were further sub-divided into townships measuring approximately .

The counties are no longer used as administrative boundaries for the provincial government; however, they continue to be used as census divisions by Statistics Canada for statistical purposes in administering the Canadian census.

See also

Administrative divisions of Canada

References

 
Counties
Prince Edward Island

easy_general.text:
Prince Edward Island, a province in Canada, is divided into three counties. These counties were first set up by Captain Samuel Holland in 1764-65. Holland was part of the British Army and did this work as part of his job. Each county had a main town called a "royalty," where important government things happened. The area outside these towns was split into smaller parts called parishes, mostly for the Church of England. Parishes were then divided into even smaller areas called townships.

Today, these counties are not used for running the province, but they still help count people for the government. Statistics Canada, which collects information about the population, uses these counties for their studies.

For more details on how other places in Canada are organized, you can look at "Administrative divisions of Canada."

adult_non_technical.text:
Prince Edward Island, a province in Canada, has a unique history when it comes to organizing its land. Before joining Canada in 1873, the island was divided into three areas called counties, which were used to manage local affairs.

In 1764 and 1765, a British army officer named Captain Samuel Holland drew up detailed maps of the island. He split the land into these three counties, each with a special town called a "royalty" or "shire town." This town served as the center for the county. Outside these towns, the land was further divided into smaller areas known as parishes, which were about 20 square miles each. Parishes were then broken down into even smaller units called townships, roughly 4 square miles in size.

Today, these counties don't play a role in how the provincial government runs things. However, they still matter for counting people and gathering information. Statistics Canada, the agency responsible for collecting data in Canada, uses these counties to organize census information.

This system of dividing the land into counties, parishes, and townships is part of the broader way Canada organizes its regions. If you want to learn more about how different parts of Canada are structured, you can read about the administrative divisions of the country.

For more details on this topic, you might want to check out resources on the administrative divisions of Canada.

adult_technical.text:
The Canadian province of Prince Edward Island historically utilized three counties as administrative divisions under both the colonial and provincial governments, with the system dating back to the 18th century.

The current land division system in Prince Edward Island, encompassing these three counties, originated from surveys conducted between 1764 and 1765 by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army's Royal Engineers. Holland's surveys delineated the island into three counties, each with a designated "royalty" or shire town serving as the county seat. The remaining areas within each county were further subdivided into parishes, roughly measuring 20 square miles, and these parishes were subsequently divided into townships, approximately 4 square miles in size.

Although the counties are no longer employed as administrative boundaries by the provincial government, they persist as census divisions managed by Statistics Canada for demographic and statistical purposes.

For additional context, see "Administrative Divisions of Canada."

References:

Counties
Prince Edward Island

samples.title: Murray River National Park
samples.original_text:
Murray River National Park is a protected area  in South Australia located between  and  north east of the Adelaide city centre.  The national park was proclaimed in 1991 "to conserve a significant proportion of South Australia’s floodplain environments which are not represented widely in other reserve systems."  The national park consists of three sections adjoining the Murray River and extending from near Loxton in the south west to near Renmark in the north-east.  The first which is known as the ‘Katarapko’ section is located on the north side of the river between Loxton in the south and Berri in the north.  The second section which is known as the ‘Lyrup Flats’ section is located on the north side of the river midway between Berri and Loxton.  The third section is known as the ‘Bulyong’ section is located on the west side of the river upstream from Renmark.     The national park is classified as an IUCN Category VI protected area.

See also
 Protected areas of South Australia
 Katarapko Game Reserve
 Riverland Biosphere Reserve
 List of islands within the Murray River in South Australia
 Riverland Mallee Important Bird Area

References

External links
 Murray River National Park official site
Murray River National Park webpage on protected planet

National parks of South Australia
Protected areas established in 1991
1991 establishments in Australia
Murray River

easy_general.text:
Murray River National Park is a special area in South Australia. It's about halfway between Adelaide and the northeast part of the state. This park was made in 1991 to protect parts of the floodplains that aren't found in many other parks.

The park has three main parts. They are:

1. **Katarapko Section**: This part is on the north side of the Murray River, stretching from Loxton in the south to Berri in the north.
2. **Lyrup Flats Section**: Also on the north side of the river, this section is between Berri and Loxton.
3. **Bulyong Section**: This part is on the west side of the river, upstream from Renmark.

These sections help protect different areas along the Murray River. The park is considered an IUCN Category VI protected area, which means it focuses on conservation and sustainable use of natural resources.

### Related Information
- **Protected Areas in South Australia**: Learn more about other protected areas in the state.
- **Katarapko Game Reserve**: A smaller protected area nearby.
- **Riverland Biosphere Reserve**: Another protected area focusing on the environment.
- **Islands in the Murray River**: Discover the islands within the river.
- **Birds in the Riverland Mallee**: Find out about important bird areas in the region.

### More Details
- **Official Site**: Visit the official website for more information.
- **Protected Planet Webpage**: Check out the webpage on Protected Planet for details.

### Other Parks in South Australia
- **Other National Parks**: See a list of other national parks in the state.
- **Establishments in 1991**: Learn about other parks and protected areas that were created in 1991.
- **Murray River**: Read more about the Murray River itself.

adult_non_technical.text:
Murray River National Park is a special area in South Australia that was set aside to protect parts of the floodplains along the Murray River. It was officially declared in 1991 to preserve these unique environments, which aren't well-represented in other protected areas.

The park covers about 25,000 hectares (around 62,000 acres) and is divided into three sections:

1. **Katarapko Section**: This part is on the north side of the river, stretching from Loxton in the southwest to Berri in the northeast.
2. **Lyrup Flats Section**: Also on the north side of the river, this section lies between Berri and Loxton.
3. **Bulyong Section**: This section is on the west side of the river, upstream from Renmark.

These sections work together to form a larger protected area that helps maintain the natural balance of the region. The park is considered an "IUCN Category VI" protected area, which means it's designed to conserve ecosystems and biodiversity while allowing sustainable human activities like recreation and education.

This park is part of a broader network of protected areas in South Australia, including the Riverland Biosphere Reserve and the Riverland Mallee Important Bird Area. It plays a crucial role in preserving the unique floodplain environments along the Murray River, ensuring that future generations can enjoy and learn from these natural wonders.

For more information, you can visit the [Murray River National Park official website](https://www.murrayrivernationalpark.com/) or check out the [protected planet page](https://www.protectedplanet.net/parks/murray-river-national-park).

This park is one of many in South Australia that were established in 1991, contributing to the country's efforts to protect its natural heritage.

adult_technical.text:
Murray River National Park is a protected area in South Australia, situated approximately northeast of Adelaide's city center. Proclaimed in 1991, its primary objective is to preserve a significant portion of South Australia’s floodplain environments that are underrepresented in existing conservation systems. Spanning an extensive area along the Murray River, the park encompasses three distinct sections: Katarapko, Lyrup Flats, and Bulyong. 

The Katarapko section, located on the north bank of the river, extends from Loxton in the southwest to Berri in the northeast. The Lyrup Flats section, also on the north bank, lies midway between Berri and Loxton. Lastly, the Bulyong section, situated on the west bank upstream from Renmark, completes the park's layout.

Murray River National Park is categorized as an IUCN Category VI protected area, emphasizing its role in habitat conservation without strict ecological restoration or preservation measures.

For further reading and additional information, see:

- **Protected Areas of South Australia**
- **Katarapko Game Reserve**
- **Riverland Biosphere Reserve**
- **List of Islands within the Murray River in South Australia**
- **Riverland Mallee Important Bird Area**

For official information and more details, visit:

- [Murray River National Park Official Site](#)
- [Murray River National Park Webpage on Protected Planet](#)

This park is part of the broader national park system in South Australia and among the protected areas established in 1991 in Australia.

samples.title: Tuireann
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann (Old Irish: Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo) was the father by Danu (or Brigid) of Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu.

His other sons, by his daughter Danand, included Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba, who killed Lugh's father Cian. As an erec (a recompense fine), they were sent on a quest recounted as Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann (The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann), one of the Three sorrowful tales of Erin. After Lugh had taken his elaborate revenge, Tuireann died of grief over their graves.

He is stated in various portions of Lebor Gabála Érenn to be the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also credited as the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References

Tuatha Dé Danann

easy_general.text:
In Irish stories, there was a character named Tuireann. He had three sons with a goddess named Danu or Brigid—Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu.

Tuireann also had another set of sons through his daughter Danand. These sons were Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. They did something very bad—they killed Lugh's father, Cian. Because of this, they had to go on a dangerous journey. This story is called "The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann." After Lugh took his revenge, Tuireann was so sad that he died near his sons' graves.

Some old books say that Tuireann was actually the same as Delbáeth, another character. Delbáeth was also said to be the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

These stories come from ancient Irish writings known as "Lebor Gabála Érenn," which tells about the history and gods of Ireland.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Irish myths, there was a character named Tuireann (also known as Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo). He had three sons with a goddess named Danu (or Brigid): Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu. These sons were skilled craftsmen.

Tuireann also had another set of sons through his daughter Danand—Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. These sons did something very naughty; they killed Lugh's father, Cian. As punishment, Lugh made them go on a dangerous quest, which is described in a story called "The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann." This tale is one of the most sorrowful stories from ancient Ireland.

After Lugh took his revenge, Tuireann was so sad about losing his sons that he died from grief, lying beside their graves.

Interestingly, in different parts of an old book called "Lebor Gabála Érenn," Tuireann is said to be the same as another character named Delbáeth mac Ogma. Both are mentioned as the fathers of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

This story comes from the Tuatha Dé Danann, a group of gods and heroes in Irish mythology.

adult_technical.text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann (also known as Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo) is a figure who, through his union with Danu or Brigid, fathered three blacksmiths: Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu. Additionally, he sired Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba with his daughter Danand. These latter sons were responsible for the murder of Lugh's father, Cian. As reparation, they were tasked with a perilous quest detailed in "Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann" (The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann), one of the Three Sorrowful Tales of Erin. Following Lugh's elaborate and vengeful response, Tuireann succumbed to grief upon learning of his sons' fates.

Tuireann is sometimes conflated with Delbáeth mac Ogma, another deity, who is also acknowledged as the progenitor of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. This conflation is documented in various sections of the "Lebor Gabála Érenn," an ancient Irish text detailing the genealogies and migrations of the Tuatha Dé Danann, a race of deities and semi-divine beings in Irish mythology.

References:

- Tuatha Dé Danann

samples.title: Optimization (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
Mathematical optimization is the theory and computation of extrema or stationary points of functions.

Optimization, optimisation, or optimality may also refer to:

 Engineering optimization
 Feedback-Directed Optimisation, in computing
 Optimality model in biology
 Optimality Theory, in linguistics
 Optimization (role-playing games), a gaming play style
 Optimize (magazine)
 Process optimization, in business and engineering, methodologies for improving the efficiency of a production process
 Product optimization, in business and marketing, methodologies for improving the quality and desirability of a product or product concept
 Program optimization, in computing, methodologies for improving the efficiency of software
 Search engine optimization, in internet marketing

See also 

 Optimum (disambiguation)
 Optimality theory (disambiguation)
 Optimism (disambiguation)
 Optimist (disambiguation)
 Optimistic (disambiguation)
 
 Maximization (disambiguation)
 Minimization (disambiguation)

easy_general.text:
Optimization is about finding the best solution or the highest or lowest point in a situation. Here’s what it means in different areas:

1. **Engineering Optimization**: This is like making sure a bridge or a car works as well as possible. Engineers find ways to make things stronger or more efficient.

2. **Feedback-Directed Optimization**: In computers, this is about making programs run faster or better by getting feedback on how they perform.

3. **Optimality Model in Biology**: Scientists use this to understand how animals or plants make the best choices for survival.

4. **Optimality Theory in Linguistics**: Linguists use this to figure out the best way people speak or write languages.

5. **Optimization in Role-Playing Games**: Players try to get the most points or rewards in the game.

6. **Optimize Magazine**: A magazine that talks about making things better.

7. **Process Optimization in Business and Engineering**: This is about making factories or businesses work more efficiently. For example, finding the best way to assemble a toy or produce a car part.

8. **Product Optimization in Business and Marketing**: This is about making products better. For instance, improving a smartphone to make it more appealing to customers.

9. **Program Optimization in Computing**: This involves making computer programs run faster and use less memory.

10. **Search Engine Optimization in Internet Marketing**: This is about making websites easier for search engines to find and display higher in search results.

These terms all relate to finding the best way to do something, whether it's in nature, technology, or everyday life.

adult_non_technical.text:
Mathematical optimization is about finding the best possible solution or the most efficient way to do something. It's like trying to find the highest point on a mountain or the lowest point in a valley, but for more complex problems.

The term "optimization" can mean different things depending on the field:

- **Engineering Optimization**: This is about making machines, buildings, or any kind of structure work better and more efficiently.
- **Feedback-Directed Optimization**: In computing, this involves making computer programs run faster by adjusting how they work based on how they perform.
- **Optimality Model in Biology**: Scientists use this to understand how living things make decisions that help them survive.
- **Optimality Theory in Linguistics**: Linguists use this to explain how people choose the best way to say things when speaking.
- **Optimization in Role-Playing Games**: Players try to find the best strategies or paths to win or achieve their goals.
- **Optimize Magazine**: A publication focused on helping businesses and individuals improve their processes.
- **Process Optimization in Business and Engineering**: This is about making factories, offices, or any other place where work happens run smoother and more efficiently.
- **Product Optimization in Business and Marketing**: Companies use this to make their products better and more appealing to customers.
- **Program Optimization in Computing**: This involves making computer programs run faster and use less memory.
- **Search Engine Optimization in Internet Marketing**: This is about making websites easier for search engines to find and rank higher in search results.

These are just a few examples of how the idea of optimization is used in different areas. The goal is always to find the best way to do something, whether it's making a product better, a program faster, or a process more efficient.

adult_technical.text:
Mathematical optimization encompasses the theoretical and computational aspects of identifying extrema or stationary points of functions. This field has broad applications across various disciplines, including:

1. **Engineering Optimization**: The application of mathematical techniques to enhance the performance and efficiency of engineering systems.

2. **Feedback-Directed Optimization**: A methodology in computer science where optimization decisions are influenced by feedback mechanisms during the execution of algorithms.

3. **Optimality Model in Biology**: A framework used to explain and predict biological phenomena based on the principle that organisms evolve to achieve optimal outcomes under given constraints.

4. **Optimality Theory in Linguistics**: A theoretical approach that posits linguistic structures are optimized for certain communicative purposes, often through the minimization of cognitive effort.

5. **Optimization in Role-Playing Games**: A gaming strategy focused on maximizing character or player effectiveness through efficient resource management and strategic decision-making.

6. **Optimize Magazine**: A publication dedicated to discussing and promoting best practices in optimization across different fields.

7. **Process Optimization in Business and Engineering**: Systematic approaches aimed at improving the efficiency and effectiveness of production processes.

8. **Product Optimization in Business and Marketing**: Techniques employed to refine and enhance the quality and market appeal of products or product concepts.

9. **Program Optimization in Computing**: Methods for enhancing the performance and efficiency of software through code refinement and algorithmic improvements.

10. **Search Engine Optimization (SEO)**: Strategies used to improve the visibility and ranking of websites in search engine results, thereby increasing organic traffic.

For further exploration, related concepts include:

- **Optimum (Disambiguation)**: Various interpretations of the term "optimum" across different contexts.
- **Optimality Theory (Disambiguation)**: Different applications and interpretations of optimality theory in various fields.
- **Optimism (Disambiguation)**: Multiple meanings and implications of optimism in psychology, philosophy, and other domains.
- **Optimist (Disambiguation)**: Different types and characteristics of optimists in society and culture.
- **Optimistic (Disambiguation)**: Various uses and connotations of the adjective "optimistic."

Additionally, related concepts include:

- **Maximization (Disambiguation)**: Different approaches and methods to maximize quantities or values.
- **Minimization (Disambiguation)**: Various techniques and strategies for minimizing quantities or costs.

samples.title: 186 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 186 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Albinus and Philippus (or, less frequently, year 568 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 186 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 The rapid spread of the Bacchanalia cult throughout the Roman Republic, which, it is claimed, indulges in all kinds of crimes and political conspiracies at its nocturnal meetings, leads to the Roman Senate issuing a decree, the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus, by which the Bacchanalia are prohibited throughout all Italy except in certain special cases which must be approved specifically by the Senate.

 Asia Minor 
 Eumenes II of Pergamum defeats Prusias I of Bithynia.

 China 
 The first burial at the famous archaeological site of Mawangdui is made during the Western Han Dynasty of China.

Births 
 Ptolemy VI Philometor, king of Egypt, who will reign from 180 BC (d. 145 BC)

Deaths 
 Li Cang, Marquis of Dai, buried in one of the Mawangdui

References

easy_general.text:
In 186 BC, which was before the Julian calendar was introduced, the Roman Republic was ruled by two leaders called consuls named Albinus and Philippus. This year is also known as the 568th year since Rome was founded.

Events:

Roman Republic:
The Roman Senate banned a secret religious group called the Bacchanalia because they thought the group was involved in illegal activities and political plots during their nighttime meetings. The only places where the Bacchanalia could still meet were those approved by the Senate.

Asia Minor:
King Eumenes II of Pergamum defeated King Prusias I of Bithynia in a battle.

China:
During the Western Han Dynasty, the first burial took place at a famous archaeological site called Mawangdui.

Births:
Ptolemy VI Philometor, who would become the king of Egypt, was born in 186 BC and lived until 145 BC.

Deaths:
Li Cang, a nobleman known as the Marquis of Dai, was buried at Mawangdui.

Note: The term "Marquis" refers to a high-ranking noble title in ancient China.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 186 BC, which was before the Julian calendar was introduced, Rome was led by two consuls named Albinus and Philippus. This year is also marked as the 568th year since Rome was founded. Since then, people have been using the year 186 BC to refer to this time.

Key Events:

Roman Republic:
A cult called Bacchanalia, which involved secret nighttime gatherings where people were said to commit various crimes and plot against the government, began spreading rapidly across the Roman Republic. In response, the Roman Senate issued a rule, known as the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus, banning the Bacchanalia throughout Italy, with a few exceptions that needed Senate approval.

Asia Minor:
King Eumenes II of Pergamum defeated King Prusias I of Bithynia in battle.

China:
During the Western Han Dynasty, the first burial at the famous archaeological site of Mawangdui took place.

Notable Births:
Ptolemy VI Philometor, who would become the king of Egypt starting in 180 BC, was born this year.

Notable Deaths:
Li Cang, a Marquis of Dai, was buried at the Mawangdui site.

These events provide a snapshot of what was happening in different parts of the world around 2,200 years ago.

adult_technical.text:
In 186 BC, the Roman Republic faced significant challenges as the Bacchanalia cult rapidly expanded, allegedly engaging in criminal activities and political conspiracies during its nocturnal gatherings. This led to the issuance of the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus, a decree by the Roman Senate that banned the cult across Italy, with specific exceptions requiring Senate approval.

In Asia Minor, Eumenes II of Pergamum secured a military victory over Prusias I of Bithynia, enhancing Pergamum's regional influence.

During the Western Han Dynasty in China, the Mawangdui archaeological site saw its first burial, marking the beginning of a rich historical record.

Notable births included Ptolemy VI Philometor, who would ascend to the throne of Egypt in 180 BC and rule until his death in 145 BC.

Li Cang, Marquis of Dai, was interred in one of the Mawangdui tombs, contributing to the archaeological significance of the site.

These events highlight the complex political and cultural dynamics of the late Hellenistic and early Han periods.

samples.title: Dodoni
samples.original_text:
Dodoni () is a village and a municipality in the Ioannina regional unit, Epirus, Greece. The seat of the municipality is the village Agia Kyriaki (community Theriakisi).

The modern village of Dodoni is located near the ancient city of same name and site of the ancient oracle of Dodona. Oedipus the King was shot here in 1967.

Municipality
The present municipality Dodoni was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 4 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Agios Dimitrios
Dodoni
Lakka Souliou
Selloi

The municipality Dodoni has an area of 657.499 km2, the municipal unit Dodoni has an area of 101.016 km2, and the community Dodoni has an area of 8.748 km2.

Gallery

References

Populated places in Ioannina (regional unit)
Municipalities of Epirus (region)
Cities in ancient Greece

easy_general.text:
Dodoni is a small town in Greece. It's part of a bigger area called the Ioannina regional unit, which is in a region named Epirus. The main village in this area is called Agia Kyriaki.

Nearby, there used to be an ancient city also named Dodoni. This city was famous because it had a special place where people would go to get advice from the gods. A famous story about Oedipus the King was filmed here in 1967.

Now, Dodoni is made up of four smaller areas that came together in 2011. These areas are:
- Agios Dimitrios
- Dodoni
- Lakka Souliou
- Selloi

The whole area of Dodoni covers 657 square kilometers. The main part of Dodoni covers 101 square kilometers, and the village of Dodoni itself covers 8.7 square kilometers.

Here are some pictures of Dodoni and its surroundings.

For more information, you can look at:
- Other towns in Ioannina
- Towns in the Epirus region
- Important cities in ancient Greece

adult_non_technical.text:
Dodoni is a small town and its surrounding area in Greece. It's part of a region called Epirus, which is in the northern part of the country. The main village in this area is called Agia Kyriaki, though there’s also another village nearby named Theriakisi.

The modern town of Dodoni stands close to the ruins of an ancient city with the same name. This ancient city was famous for its oracle, where people would go to seek advice from the gods. Interestingly, a movie about Oedipus the King was filmed here in 1967.

In 2011, the local government decided to combine four smaller areas into one larger one. These areas were:

1. Agios Dimitrios
2. Dodoni
3. Lakka Souliou
4. Selloi

Now, the new combined area is called the municipality of Dodoni. Here are the sizes of these areas:

- The whole municipality covers 657 square kilometers.
- The municipal unit Dodoni covers 101 square kilometers.
- The community Dodoni itself covers just 8.75 square kilometers.

If you want to see more about the area, you can look at a gallery or find more information on populated places in Ioannina and the municipalities of Epirus. There’s also a list of cities from ancient Greece if you’re interested in learning more about that time period.

adult_technical.text:
Dodoni is a village and municipality located within the Ioannina regional unit of Epirus, Greece. The administrative seat of the municipality is the village of Agia Kyriaki, which is part of the community Theriakisi.

The modern village of Dodoni is situated near its ancient namesake, the site of the renowned ancient oracle of Dodona. Notably, this region was also the scene of a significant event in 1967, where Oedipus the King was shot.

Administrative Structure
Following the 2011 local government reform, the current municipality of Dodoni was established through the consolidation of four former municipalities into municipal units:
1. Agios Dimitrios
2. Dodoni
3. Lakka Souliou
4. Selloi

Geographical Details
The municipality of Dodoni encompasses an area of 657.499 km², while the municipal unit of Dodoni covers 101.016 km², and the community of Dodoni occupies 8.748 km².

For additional context, readers may refer to the following resources:
- Populated places in the Ioannina regional unit
- Municipalities of Epirus (region)
- Cities in ancient Greece

easy_general.text:

Places:

- Italy: In Lazio, there's a small town called Ausonia. There was also an ancient city called Ausona, which was once the main city of the Ausones.

Mars:
- On Mars, there are two features named Ausonia: Ausonia Mensa, a flat area, and Ausonia Montes, a mountain range.

Ships:

- In 1921, Britain had a big boat called Ausonia that could carry lots of people.
- Italy had a cruise ship called Ausonia in 1956.
- A fast ferry called Cruise Ausonia started running in 2002.

Sports:

Organizations:

- In Italy, there's a political group called Lega Sud Ausonia.

Other:

Related terms:

- Aurunci: Another ancient group of people in Italy.
- Ausonium: An old name for a place in Italy.
- Ausonius (310–395): A famous poet who lived in the fourth century.

adult_technical.text:

samples.title: Florence, Illinois
samples.original_text:
Florence is a village in Pike County, Illinois, United States. The population was 71 at the 2000 census.

Geography
Florence is located at  (39.628248, −90.610328).

According to the 2010 census, Florence has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 71 people, 30 households, and 21 families residing in the village. The population density was 350.4 people per square mile (137.1/km). There were 45 housing units at an average density of 222.1 per square mile (86.9/km). The racial makeup of the village was 100.00% White.

There were 30 households, out of which 16.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 50.0% were married couples living together, 16.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.0% were non-families. 23.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.37 and the average family size was 2.67.

In the village, the population was spread out, with 22.5% under the age of 18, 5.6% from 18 to 24, 22.5% from 25 to 44, 26.8% from 45 to 64, and 22.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 44 years. For every 100 females, there were 115.2 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.7 males.

The median income for a household in the village was $20,000, and the median income for a family was $22,679. Males had a median income of $19,000 versus $20,625 for females. The per capita income for the village was $9,878. There were 8.0% of families and 15.1% of the population living below the poverty line, including no under eighteens and 5.0% of those over 64.

References

Villages in Pike County, Illinois
Villages in Illinois

Location
Florence is at coordinates 39.628248, -90.610328.

Size
Florence covers an area of about 0.21 square miles, all of which is land.

People
In 2000, there were 71 people, 30 families, and 45 houses in Florence. The village was very crowded, with 350 people per square mile.

Households
Out of the 30 households, only a few had children under 18. Half of the households were married couples, while one-sixth had a single woman as the head. About one-third of the households were not families, either because they were single people or older adults living alone.

The village had a mix of ages. About 22% of the people were under 18, 22% were between 25 and 44, 27% were between 45 and 64, and 22% were 65 or older. The average age was 44.

For every 100 women, there were slightly more men—115.2 to be exact. Among women aged 18 and over, there were fewer men—only 89.7 for every 100 women.

Income
The average income for a household was $20,000, and for a family, it was $22,679. Men earned a bit less than women on average. The money each person earned (per capita income) was $9,878. About 8% of families and 15% of the total population lived below the poverty line, but there were no poor children and only 5% of people over 64 were poor.

This information helps us understand what life was like in Florence back then.

samples.title: Daigo
samples.original_text:
Daigo may refer to:

Buddhism
Daigo (Zen) (大悟), a Buddhist term meaning great enlightenment or great realization
Daigo (Shōbōgenzō) (大悟), or Great Realization, a book in Eihei Dōgen's Shōbōgenzō
Daigo Temple (醍醐寺), from which Emperor Daigo took his name

People
Emperor Daigo (醍醐天皇), Emperor of Japan between 897 and 930
Daigo family, a branch of the Ichijō family of Japanese nobility
Daigo (musician) (born 1978), Japanese singer-songwriter, actor, talent, and voice actor
Daigo (name)
Daigo Umehara, or simply "Daigo", Japanese competitive fighting game player

Places
Daigo, Fushimi, Kyoto, a district in the ward of Fushimi-ku, Kyoto
Daigo Station (Kyoto) (醍醐駅), a train station
Daigo Station (Akita) (醍醐駅), a train station
Daigo, Ibaraki (大子町), a town in Ibaraki Prefecture

Other uses

, aka  from Gosei Sentai Dairanger

easy_general.text:
Daigo can mean different things:

1. **Buddhism**: In Buddhism, Daigo means a big moment of understanding or realization. It's like when you suddenly get something really important after thinking about it for a long time.

2. **A Book**: There's a book called Daigo (Great Realization) written by a man named Eihei Dōgen. This book talks about deep spiritual ideas.

3. **A Temple**: Daigo Temple is a special place where people go to pray and learn about Buddhism. The temple got its name from an emperor who lived a long time ago.

4. **People**:
   - **Emperor Daigo**: He was a king of Japan who ruled from 897 to 930.
   - **Daigo Family**: They were part of a noble family in Japan with the last name Ichijō.
   - **Daigo (Musician)**: This is a person who sings songs and acts in movies. His full name is Daigo Umehara.
   - **Daigo (Name)**: This is just someone's name, like John or Mary.

5. **Places**:
   - **Daigo, Fushimi, Kyoto**: This is a neighborhood in a city called Kyoto.
   - **Daigo Station (Kyoto)**: It's a train stop where people can get on and off trains.
   - **Daigo Station (Akita)**: Another train stop, but in a different part of Japan.
   - **Daigo, Ibaraki**: This is a small town in a place called Ibaraki.

6. **Other Uses**:
   - **Daigo (Dairy Product)**: This is a type of butter called ghee, which might have been made in old Japan.
   - **Gosei Sentai Dairanger**: This is a part of a TV show about superheroes.

For more information, you can look up Daigou, which is when people buy things from other countries without permission.

**People**

samples.title: Pane carasau
samples.original_text:
Pane carasau (, ; "toasted bread" in Sardinian language, from the past participle of the Sardinian verb  "to toast", referring to the crust) is a traditional flatbread from Sardinia. It is called  in Italian, meaning "sheet music", in reference to its large and paper-thin shape, which is said to be so thin before cooking that a sheet of music can be read through it.

The bread is thin and crisp, usually in the form of a dish half a meter wide. It is made by taking baked flat bread (made of durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water), then separating it into two sheets which are baked again. The recipe is very ancient and was conceived for shepherds, who used to stay far from home for months at a time: pane carasau can last up to one year if it is kept dry. The bread can be eaten either dry or wet (with water, wine, or sauces). A similar, yeast-free bread, with added seasoning, is known as  "dripped bread".

Remains of the bread were found in archeological excavations of nuraghes (traditional Sardinian stone buildings) and it was therefore already eaten on the island prior to 1000 BC.

References

External links
 A video showing the production of Pane carasau
 History of Pane Carasau

Italian breads
Flatbreads
Cuisine of Sardinia
Ancient dishes

easy_general.text:
Pane carasau is a traditional flatbread from Sardinia. In Sardinian, it means "toasted bread." This bread is very thin and crispy, often about half a meter wide. It's made from durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water. After baking, it's split into two thin sheets and baked again. This process makes the bread very durable—it can last up to a year if kept dry. People can eat it dry or with water, wine, or sauces.

In Sardinian, it’s also called "carta di musica," which means "sheet music." This name comes from the bread's thin, paper-like appearance. Shepherds used to make this bread because it could last a long time, even months, without going bad. They would keep it dry to preserve it.

Archaeologists have found remains of this bread in ancient Sardinian buildings called nuraghes, dating back before 1000 BC. This shows that people were eating pane carasau long ago.

A similar, yeast-free bread with added flavors is called "pane ristretto."

You can watch a video showing how to make pane carasau and learn more about its history.

adult_non_technical.text:
Pane carasau is a traditional flatbread from the island of Sardinia. In Sardinian, it means "toasted bread," referring to its crispy, toasted crust. Interestingly, the name also comes from the Italian word for "sheet music," because the bread is so thin that you can almost read through it when it's fresh!

This bread is very thin and crisp, often about half a meter wide. To make it, bakers start with a flatbread made from durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water. They bake it, then split it into two layers and bake it again. This process makes the bread extra crispy and long-lasting. In fact, if stored properly, it can last up to a whole year! People can enjoy it either dry or with water, wine, or sauces.

The history of this bread goes back a long way. Archaeologists have found remains of pane carasau in ancient Sardinian stone buildings called nuraghes, suggesting that people were eating it before 1000 BC. This makes it a very old and traditional food, especially suited for shepherds who needed something durable and nutritious while tending their flocks far from home.

Pane carasau is just one type of flatbread from Sardinia. Another similar bread, without yeast and seasoned with various ingredients, is called "dripped bread." Both are part of the rich culinary heritage of Sardinia.

If you're interested in learning more about how pane carasau is made or its historical significance, there are videos and articles available online that delve deeper into its production and history.

adult_technical.text:
Pane carasau, a traditional flatbread from Sardinia, derives its name from the Sardinian term "carasu," meaning "toasted bread," specifically referring to the toasted crust. In Italian, it is also known as "carta di musica," literally "sheet music," owing to its large, paper-thin form, which can reportedly be translucent enough to read through when fresh.

This bread is characterized by its thinness and crisp texture, often measuring approximately half a meter in diameter. Its preparation involves starting with a baked flatbread made from durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water, which is then divided into two sheets and baked again. This process results in a durable product that can last up to a year when stored in a dry environment, making it ideal for shepherds who frequently traveled long distances away from home for extended periods.

Pane carasau can be consumed both dry and moistened with water, wine, or sauces. A variant without yeast and seasoned with various ingredients is known as "pane ristretto."

Archaeological evidence suggests that this bread was consumed in Sardinia prior to 1000 BC, as remains have been found in nuraghes, traditional Sardinian stone structures.

For further information, see the following references:

- A video demonstrating the production of Pane carasau.
- An article detailing the history of Pane carasau.

samples.original_text:
Year 346 (CCCXLVI) was a common year starting on Wednesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. In the Roman Empire, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Constantius and Claudius (or, less frequently, year 1099 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 346 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
 Asia 
 In Korea, the Buyeo Kingdom is absorbed by Goguryeo.
 Geunchogo becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

 By topic 
 Religion 
 Emperor Constans I uses his influence to secure the return of Athanasius. He is restored as Patriarch of Alexandria, and documents are compiled relating to his expulsion, under the title Apology Against the Arians.
 Macedonius I, Patriarch of Constantinople, is deposed again by Paul I.
 Julius Firmicus Maternus writes De erroribus profanarum religionum.
 The Visigoths are converted to Arianism by Wulfila.

Births 
 Zhang Tianxi, Chinese ruler of Former Liang (d. 406)

Deaths 
 He Chong (or Cidao), Chinese politician (b. 292)
 Maximin of Trier, German bishop (approximate date)
 Zhang Jun (or Gongting), Chinese prince (b. 307)

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 346, which was a regular year starting on a Wednesday according to the Julian calendar, some interesting events happened:

### Events

#### Places
- **Asia**
  - In Korea, the kingdom of Buyeo was taken over by Goguryeo.
  - Geunchogo became the king of the kingdom of Baekje.

#### Religion
- **Religion**
  - Emperor Constans I helped bring Athanasius back to power. Athanasius was made the leader of the church in Alexandria again. Documents about why he was removed before were collected and put together in a book called "Apology Against the Arians."
  - Macedonius I, who was the leader of the church in Constantinople, was removed from his position again by Paul I.
  - Julius Firmicus Maternus wrote a book titled "De erroribus profanarum religionum."
  - The Visigoths, a group of people, started following a type of Christianity called Arianism after being taught by Wulfila.

### Births
- **Births**
  - Zhang Tianxi, who later ruled a part of China called Former Liang, was born.

### Deaths
- **Deaths**
  - He Chong (or Cidao), a Chinese leader, died around 346.
  - Maximin of Trier, a German bishop, died around the same time.
  - Zhang Jun (or Gongting), a Chinese prince, died in 346.

These events show how different parts of the world were changing during this time.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 346, which began on a Wednesday according to the Julian calendar, several significant events took place around the world. This year is also known as the 1099th year since the founding of Rome.

### Events

#### By Place

**Asia**
- **Korea:** The kingdom of Buyeo was taken over by Goguryeo.
- **Baekje:** Geunchogo became the king of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

#### By Topic

**Religion**
- **Athanasius:** Emperor Constans I helped bring Athanasius back to power. Athanasius had previously been removed from his position as the leader of the Christian church in Alexandria, Egypt. Now, he was allowed to return and write about why he was wronged, which is called "Apology Against the Arians."
- **Macedonius I:** The leader of the Christian church in Constantinople, Macedonius I, was removed from his position again by Paul I.
- **Julius Firmicus Maternus:** This writer produced a book titled "De erroribus profanarum religionum," which discusses errors in non-Christian religions.
- **Visigoths:** The Visigoths, a group of people who lived in Europe, adopted a form of Christianity called Arianism after being influenced by Wulfila.

**Births**
- **Zhang Tianxi:** Born in China, he later became the ruler of a kingdom called Former Liang and lived until 406.

**Deaths**
- **He Chong (or Cidao):** A Chinese politician who lived from 292 to 346.
- **Maximin of Trier:** A German bishop who died around the same time as He Chong.
- **Zhang Jun (or Gongting):** A Chinese prince born in 307 and died in 346.

These events show how different regions and cultures were changing during this time, including political shifts, religious movements, and the lives of notable figures.

adult_technical.text:
In the Julian calendar, the year 346 (CCCXLVI) was a common year beginning on a Wednesday. Historically, this year is also referred to as the Year of the Consulship of Constantius and Claudius within the Roman Empire, or as the 1099th year from the founding of Rome (Ab urbe condita). The Anno Domini system, which became prevalent in Europe during the early medieval period, designated this year as 346.

### Events

#### By Place

**Asia**

- **Korea**: The Buyeo Kingdom was annexed by Goguryeo, marking a significant territorial shift in the region.
- **Baekje**: Geunchogo ascended to the throne as the king of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

#### By Topic

**Religion**

- **Alexandria**: Emperor Constans I exerted his influence to facilitate the return of Athanasius, who was reinstated as the Patriarch of Alexandria. Documents pertaining to his previous expulsion were compiled under the title "Apology Against the Arians."
- **Constantinople**: Macedonius I, the Patriarch of Constantinople, was deposed once more by Paul I.
- **Literature**: Julius Firmicus Maternus authored "De erroribus profanarum religionum," a work that critiques pagan religions.
- **Visigoths**: The Visigoths converted to Arian Christianity under the leadership of Wulfila.

### Notable Births

- **Zhang Tianxi**: Born in 346, he later became the ruler of the Former Liang state in China, reigning until 406.

### Notable Deaths

- **He Chong (or Cidao)**: A Chinese politician born around 292 CE.
- **Maximin of Trier**: A German bishop, though the exact date of birth is uncertain.
- **Zhang Jun (or Gongting)**: A Chinese prince born in 307 CE.

These events provide a snapshot of the political, religious, and cultural landscape of the late 4th century, highlighting significant changes in various regions and religious movements.

samples.title: Kylix (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
A kylix or cylix is a type of drinking cup used in ancient Greece 

Kylix may also refer to:
 Kylix (gastropod), a genus of snails in the family Drilliidae
 Cylix, the genus of a pipefish, Cylix tupareomanaia
 Kylix (software), a programming tool

easy_general.text:
A kylix is a kind of cup used in ancient Greece for drinking.

Sometimes, "kylix" can mean other things too:

- A kylix can be a type of snail. These snails belong to a group called Drilliidae.
- It can also refer to a kind of fish called a pipefish. One type of pipefish is called Cylix tupareomanaia.
- In modern times, "kylix" is sometimes used as a name for a computer program that helps people write code.

adult_non_technical.text:
A kylix, also known as a cylix, is a type of drinking cup that was commonly used in ancient Greece. It's like a special kind of bowl you might drink from, but much older!

Sometimes, "kylix" can mean other things too:

1. **Kylix (snail)**: This is a type of sea snail. Imagine a small, spiral shell that lives in the ocean—this is what we call a kylix in the snail world. These snails belong to a family called Drilliidae.

2. **Cylix (pipefish)**: This is a type of fish, not to be confused with the snail! Pipefish are long, thin fish that look a bit like straws. One specific type of pipefish is called Cylix tupareomanaia.

3. **Kylix (software)**: This is a tool used by programmers. Think of it like a set of special toys that help people write computer programs more easily.

So, "kylix" can mean different things depending on where you see it used!

adult_technical.text:
A kylix, also known as a cylix, is a specific type of drinking vessel utilized in ancient Greek culture. This term, however, is also employed in various other contexts:

1. **Kylix (Gastropod)**: Refers to a genus of marine snails belonging to the family Drilliidae.
2. **Cylix (Pipefish Genus)**: Denotes a genus encompassing species such as *Cylix tupareomanaia*.
3. **Kylix (Software)**: Represents a software tool used for programming purposes.

samples.title: Tetonia, Idaho
samples.original_text:
Tetonia is a city in Teton County, Idaho, United States, about  northeast of Idaho Falls, Idaho (center to center) and about  northwest of Denver, Colorado. The population was 269 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of , all land.
Tetonia is located at 43°48′50″N 111°9′35″W, in Teton County Idaho.

History
Tetonia was established as an agricultural town in the late 19th century, taking its name from the nearby Teton Range. Many of the businesses previously operating in Haden relocated to Tetonia following the arrival of the Union Pacific railroad.

Demographics

2010 census
As of the census of 2010, there were 269 people, 95 households, and 62 families residing in the city. The population density was . There were 122 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 92.2% White, 0.7% Native American, 6.3% from other races, and 0.7% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 10.8% of the population.

There were 95 households, of which 46.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 49.5% were married couples living together, 11.6% had a female householder with no husband present, 4.2% had a male householder with no wife present, and 34.7% were non-families. 28.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.83 and the average family size was 3.61.

The median age in the city was 35.1 years. 36.1% of residents were under the age of 18; 5.1% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 26.7% were from 25 to 44; 24.5% were from 45 to 64; and 7.4% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.7% male and 51.3% female.

Tetonia covers an area of about 1 square mile, all of which is land. Its exact location is at 43°48′50″N 111°9′35″W.

**History**
Tetonia started as an agricultural town in the late 1800s. It got its name from the nearby Teton Range. When the Union Pacific railroad came, many businesses moved from a place called Haden to Tetonia.

**Demographics**
In 2010, the town had 269 people living there. There were 95 families and 122 houses. The town is mostly made up of white people, with some Native Americans, people from other races, and those from mixed backgrounds. About 11% of the population was Hispanic or Latino.

Out of the 95 households, 46% had kids under 18. About half of the households were married couples. Some households didn't have a married couple but instead had single parents or individuals living alone. About 28% of households were just one person, and 10% were older people living alone.

**Age and Gender**
The average age in Tetonia was 35.1 years. About 36% of the residents were under 18, 5% were between 18 and 24, 26.7% were between 25 and 44, 24.5% were between 45 and 64, and 7.4% were 65 or older. Slightly more women lived in Tetonia than men, with 51.3% being female and 48.7% being male.

samples.title: Hubley Township, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Hubley Township is a township in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 854 at the 2010 census, a drop of less than 1% from the previous census in 2000.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics

At the 2000 census there were 889 people, 345 households, and 260 families living in the township.  The population density was 68.0 people per square mile (26.2/km).  There were 369 housing units at an average density of 28.2/sq mi (10.9/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.21% White, 0.22% African American, 0.11% Asian, 0.22% Pacific Islander, 0.11% from other races, and 0.11% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.12%.

Of the 345 households 29.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.7% were married couples living together, 5.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.6% were non-families. 21.2% of households were one person and 11.9% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.58 and the average family size was 2.98.

The age distribution was 21.7% under the age of 18, 6.7% from 18 to 24, 28.3% from 25 to 44, 23.3% from 45 to 64, and 19.9% 65 or older.  The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 107.7 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.3 males.

The median household income was $41,250 and the median family income  was $46,538. Males had a median income of $32,734 versus $24,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $17,377.  About 4.2% of families and 5.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.6% of those under age 18 and 7.9% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Kebechet
samples.original_text:
In Egyptian mythology, Kebechet (spelt in hieroglyphs as Qeb-Hwt, and also transliterated as Khebhut, Kebehut, Qébéhout, Kabehchet and Kebehwet) is a goddess, a deification of embalming liquid. Her name means cooling water.

Myths
Kebechet is a daughter of Anubis and his wife Anput. In the Pyramid Texts, Kebechet is referred to as a serpent who "refreshes and purifies" the pharaoh.

Kebechet was thought to give water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be complete. She was probably related to mummification where she would fortify the body against corruption, so it would stay fresh for reanimation by the deceased's ka.

References

Egyptian death goddesses

easy_general.text:
In ancient Egyptian mythology, Kebechet is a goddess associated with embalming liquids. Her name means "cooling water."

Myths
Kebechet is believed to be the daughter of Anubis, the god of mummification, and his wife Anput. In some stories, Kebechet is described as a serpent that refreshes and cleans the pharaoh after death.

Role in the Afterlife
Kebechet was thought to provide water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be finished. She helped protect the body from decay, ensuring it stayed fresh until the deceased's spirit could return to it.

References
This text discusses other death goddesses in Egyptian mythology.

adult_non_technical.text:
In ancient Egyptian beliefs, Kebechet is a goddess associated with the process of preserving the dead. Her name translates to "cooling water," reflecting her role in providing refreshing and purifying water during the mummification process.

**Family and Role**
Kebechet is the daughter of Anubis, the god of mummification and the afterlife, and his wife Anput. In some myths, she is described as a serpent that brings comfort and purification to the pharaohs, ensuring their transition into the afterlife.

**Her Function**
Kebechet played a crucial role in the mummification process. It was believed that she provided the necessary water to the spirits of the deceased while they awaited the completion of the mummification. This water was essential for keeping the body fresh and preventing decay, which was important for the soul's journey to the afterlife. By fortifying the body against corruption, Kebechet helped ensure that the deceased could be revived by their ka, or life force, in the afterlife.

**Additional Context**
Kebechet is one of several death goddesses in Egyptian mythology, each with specific roles in the complex rituals surrounding death and the afterlife.

adult_technical.text:
In Egyptian mythology, Kebechet, whose hieroglyphic representation is Qeb-Hwt, is a deity associated with embalming fluids. The term "Qeb-Hwt" is derived from the Egyptian language, meaning "cooling water."

### Myths and Attributes

Kebechet is recognized as a daughter of Anubis and his consort Anput. According to the Pyramid Texts, she is described as a serpentine entity that "refreshes and purifies" the pharaoh. This role underscores her importance in the funerary rituals of ancient Egypt.

In the context of mummification, Kebechet was believed to provide hydration to the spirits of the deceased during the waiting period before the completion of the embalming process. Her function extended beyond this to include the preservation of the physical body, ensuring it remained intact and fresh for potential reanimation by the deceased's ka, or life force.

### References and Context

Kebechet is part of a broader category of Egyptian death goddesses, which includes other deities such as Nephthys, Serqet, and Neith, each with specific roles in the afterlife and funerary practices. Her significance lies in her association with the preservation of the body, a crucial aspect of Egyptian mortuary rituals aimed at facilitating the transition of the soul to the afterlife.

samples.title: Oostburg
samples.original_text:
Oostburg (Zeelandic Flemish: Wòstburg) is a town in the south-western Netherlands. It is the largest town in the municipality of Sluis, in the province of Zeeland. As of 1 January 2015, its population is 4731, down from 5008 in January 2005. It received city rights in 1237. Before 1 January 2003, Oostburg was also the name of a municipality. It merged with Sluis-Aardenburg to form the new municipality of Sluis. The municipality covered an area of 224.93 km², of which 1.05 km² was water. As well as the town of Oostburg, the former municipality also included the following towns, villages and townships:
Breskens
Cadzand
Groede
Hoofdplaat
IJzendijke
Nieuwvliet
Schoondijke
Waterlandkerkje
Zuidzande

Oostburg is typically a tourist town very close to the beaches at Cadzand. Every Wednesday is market day all year round but in the summer the town is busy and has many fun events.

The unicorn
Oostburg's symbol is the unicorn, from which the townsfolk are said to derive strength and courage. In reality, the unicorn's presence is represented by a sculpture produced by the sculptress Liesbeth Messer-Heijbroek who for many years, with her husband, lived in the area: she evidently took inspiration from the name of a former inn. The sculpture has been repositioned at least once since it first appeared in 1952 during the postwar reconstruction: at one stage it adorned a small car park. Currently it shares with a modern fountain a spot in "Eenhoornplantsoen" (Unicorn Place) beyond the northern end of the old market square in the town centre.

WW2 Monument
During the Second World War approximately 140 Oostburg townsfolk died and most of all the buildings, shops and churches were destroyed. This monument is a tribute to them and the rebuilding of the town. Around the lower part of the monument are the names of those who perished.

Cities in the Netherlands
Municipalities of the Netherlands disestablished in 2003
Populated places in Zeeland
Former municipalities of Zeeland
Sluis

adult_technical.text:
Oostburg, officially known as Wòstburg in Zeelandic Flemish, is a town located in the southwestern Netherlands within the municipality of Sluis, in the province of Zeeland. As of January 1, 2015, the town's population stood at 4,731, having decreased from 5,008 in January 2005. Oostburg received city rights in 1237. Prior to January 1, 2003, Oostburg was an independent municipality that merged with Sluis-Aardenburg to form the current municipality of Sluis. The combined municipality covers an area of 224.93 km², with 1.05 km² designated as water. Besides the town itself, the former municipality encompassed additional settlements such as Breskens, Cadzand, Groede, Hoofdplaat, IJzendijke, Nieuwvliet, Schoondijke, Waterlandkerkje, and Zuidzande.

Oostburg is primarily a tourist destination, situated near the beaches of Cadzand. Market day occurs every Wednesday throughout the year, and the town hosts numerous recreational events during the summer months. The town's emblem is a unicorn, symbolizing strength and courage for its inhabitants. This representation is embodied by a sculpture created by artist Liesbeth Messer-Heijbroek, which has been relocated multiple times since its initial installation in 1952. Currently, the sculpture stands alongside a modern fountain in "Eenhoornplantsoen" (Unicorn Place), located north of the historic market square.

During World War II, approximately 140 residents of Oostburg lost their lives, and the majority of the town's structures, including buildings, shops, and churches, were destroyed. A monument commemorates these victims and the subsequent rebuilding efforts. The names of those who perished are inscribed around the base of the monument.

Oostburg's status as a municipality changed when it merged with Sluis-Aardenburg on January 1, 2003, forming the new municipality of Sluis. This merger was part of a broader administrative restructuring in the Netherlands that took place in 2003, impacting several municipalities, particularly in the province of Zeeland.
