- Former municipalities of Zeeland

samples.title: Leaf River Township, Wadena County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Leaf River Township is a township in Wadena County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 515 at the 2000 census.

Leaf River Township was named after the Leaf River.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 515 people, 174 households, and 135 families residing in the township.  The population density was 14.6 people per square mile (5.7/km2).  There were 196 housing units at an average density of 5.6/sq mi (2.2/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 94.37% White, 2.14% African American, 1.75% Native American, 0.58% Asian, 0.19% Pacific Islander, and 0.97% from two or more races.

There were 174 households, out of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 75.9% were married couples living together, 0.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 22.4% were non-families. 21.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.68 and the average family size was 3.16.

In the township the population was spread out, with 26.2% under the age of 18, 3.9% from 18 to 24, 23.9% from 25 to 44, 33.6% from 45 to 64, and 12.4% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females, there were 138.4 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $37,292, and the median income for a family was $46,750. Males had a median income of $32,411 versus $20,795 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,681.  About 6.5% of families and 19.3% of the population were below the poverty line, including 11.1% of those under age 18 and 28.0% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: Haddocks' Eyes
samples.original_text:
"Haddocks' Eyes" is a term for the name of a song sung by The White Knight from Lewis Carroll's  1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass, chapter VIII.

"Haddocks' Eyes" is an example used to elaborate on the symbolic status of the concept of "name": a name as identification marker may be assigned to anything, including another name, thus introducing different levels of symbolization. It has been discussed in several works on logic and philosophy.

Naming

The White Knight explains to Alice a confusing nomenclature for the song.

To summarize:

The song's name is called Haddocks' Eyes
The song's name is The Aged Aged Man
The song is called Ways and Means
The song is A-sitting on a Gate

The complicated terminology distinguishing between 'the song, what the song is called, the name of the song, and what the name of the song is called' both uses and mentions the use–mention distinction.

The song

The White Knight sings the song to a tune he claims as his own invention, but which Alice recognises as "I give thee all, I can no more". By the time Alice heard it, she was already tired of poetry.

The song parodies the plot, but not the style or metre, of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth.

Upon the Lonely Moor

Like "Jabberwocky," another poem published in Through the Looking Glass, "Haddocks’ Eyes" appears to have been revised over the course of many years. In 1856, Carroll published the following poem anonymously under the name Upon the Lonely Moor. It bears an obvious resemblance to "Haddocks' Eyes."

See also

Nonsense verse

References

British poems
1871 poems
Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
Nonsense poetry
Parodies of literature

easy_general.text:
"Haddocks' Eyes" is a song from a story in a book called *Through the Looking-Glass*. This book was written by Lewis Carroll in 1871. The song is sung by a character named The White Knight.

In the story, The White Knight explains why the song has different names. Here’s how it works:

1. The song itself is called "Haddocks' Eyes."
2. But it is also known as "The Aged Aged Man."
3. The song is also referred to as "Ways and Means."
4. And it is sometimes called "A-sitting on a Gate."

These different names show how names can be tricky. They can refer to the actual song, its title, or even the name of the title. This idea is similar to something called the "use-mention distinction," where we talk about the difference between using a word and mentioning a word.

The song itself is sung to a tune that The White Knight made up. However, Alice recognizes the tune as being similar to a famous poem called "I give thee all, I can no more."

The song makes fun of another poem called "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth, but it doesn’t change the way the poem sounds or its rhythm.

Interestingly, "Haddocks' Eyes" was changed over time. In 1856, before Carroll wrote *Through the Looking-Glass*, he published a poem with a similar theme called "Upon the Lonely Moor."

This song is part of a group of funny and nonsensical poems, often called "nonsense verse." Some other poems like this include those found in *Alice's Adventures in Wonderland* and other books by Lewis Carroll.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Lewis Carroll's 1871 novel *Through the Looking-Glass*, there's a whimsical song sung by the White Knight, known as "Haddocks' Eyes." This song is a clever way to explore how names work—how they can refer to other names and create layers of meaning.

### Naming the Song

The White Knight teaches Alice about the confusing names of this song. Here’s what he says:

- The song itself is called "Haddocks' Eyes."
- But it’s also known as "The Aged Aged Man."
- The song is referred to as "Ways and Means."
- And it’s also called "A-sitting on a Gate."

These different names highlight how names can point to other names, creating a complex web of symbols.

### The Song Itself

The White Knight sings the song to a tune he claims he made up, but Alice recognizes it as a familiar tune from another poem. By the time Alice hears it, she’s already tired of poetry, showing how repetitive and perhaps tedious the song might be.

### Parody and Inspiration

The song is a playful take on the plot of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth, but it doesn’t mimic the style or rhythm of the original. Instead, it offers a humorous twist.

### Historical Context

Interestingly, "Haddocks' Eyes" seems to have evolved over time. In 1856, Carroll published a similar poem called "Upon the Lonely Moor," which shares many similarities with "Haddocks' Eyes."

### Related Topics

This poem is part of a broader category of nonsense verse, which includes other works like *Jabberwocky* from the same book. It’s also connected to British poetry from the 1870s, specifically the poems in *Alice's Adventures in Wonderland* and the genre of nonsense poetry.

Overall, "Haddocks' Eyes" is a delightful example of how names and references can create intricate layers of meaning, much like a puzzle where each piece fits into another.

adult_technical.text:
"Haddocks' Eyes" is a term derived from a song performed by the White Knight in Lewis Carroll's 1871 novel *Through the Looking-Glass*, specifically in Chapter VIII. This term exemplifies the complex nature of naming and symbolization, particularly in the context of self-referential names and multiple layers of symbolization.

### Naming Conventions

The White Knight elucidates a convoluted nomenclature for the song, which highlights the use-mention distinction—a fundamental concept in logic and philosophy. The song has several names:
- **Haddocks' Eyes**: The actual title of the song.
- **The Aged Aged Man**: Another name for the song.
- **Ways and Means**: Yet another name for the song.
- **A-sitting on a Gate**: Still another name for the song.

This intricate naming system underscores the recursive nature of names and their referents, where names can be applied to other names, thereby creating multiple levels of symbolization.

### The Song Itself

The White Knight performs the song to a tune that he claims to have invented, though Alice recognizes it as a familiar melody, "I give thee all, I can no more." Despite its familiarity, the song is presented in a manner that is likely intended to be nonsensical and whimsical, fitting within the broader context of Carroll's *Through the Looking-Glass*.

### Parodic Elements

"Haddocks' Eyes" parodies the plot of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth, but does so without mimicking the original's style or meter. This technique is reminiscent of Carroll's other nonsensical poetry, such as "Jabberwocky," which also underwent revisions over time.

### Historical Context

In 1856, Carroll published a poem under the title "Upon the Lonely Moor," which shares significant similarities with "Haddocks' Eyes." This suggests that "Haddocks' Eyes" may have evolved from earlier versions of the poem, further emphasizing Carroll's creative process and the development of his nonsensical verse.

 Eunomia (plant), a genus of plants in the family Brassicaceae
 A fictional computer in SoltyRei; see List of SoltyRei characters#Eunomia

See also 
 Callicore eunomia, a nymphalid butterfly species 
 Boloria eunomia (formerly Proclossiana eunomia eunomia), scientific names for the bog fritillary butterfly

easy_general.text:
Eunomia is a name from Greek mythology. It's used in different ways today:

- **Eunomia (moth)**: This is a type of moth. Moths are insects similar to butterflies but usually come out at night.
- **Eunomia family of asteroids**: Asteroids are like big rocks floating in space. This group of asteroids is named after the goddess Eunomia.
- **15 Eunomia**: This is the biggest asteroid in the Eunomia family. It’s called 15 because it was the 15th asteroid found and named.
- **Eunomia (plant)**: This is a type of plant. Plants are living things that grow from seeds or spores.
- **A fictional character in SoltyRei**: In a made-up story, there’s a character named Eunomia who is a computer. 

There are also some butterflies with "eunomia" in their names:

- **Callicore eunomia**: This is a kind of butterfly that belongs to a group called nymphalid butterflies.
- **Boloria eunomia**: This is another butterfly, which used to have a different name before. It’s known as the bog fritillary butterfly.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, Eunomia is a goddess who represents order and good governance. However, the name "Eunomia" has been used in various contexts outside of mythology:

- **Eunomia Moth**: This is a type of moth. Think of it as a specific kind of flying insect.
- **Eunomia Asteroids**: These are space rocks that orbit the sun. They were named after the goddess because they represent order and good management, just like Eunomia does.
- **15 Eunomia**: This is the biggest rock in the Eunomia group of asteroids. It's like the leader of a team of space rocks!
- **Eunomia Plant**: This is a type of plant, part of a larger group called Brassicaceae. Imagine it as a specific kind of flower or vegetable.
- **Eunomia in SoltyRei**: In this fictional world, Eunomia is a character. You can find more about her in the list of characters from SoltyRei.

There are also some butterflies that have "Eunomia" in their names:

- **Callicore Eunomia**: This is a type of butterfly. Think of it as a pretty flying insect with colorful wings.
- **Boloria Eunomia**: This is another butterfly, previously known as Proclossiana eunomia eunomia. It’s often called the bog fritillary butterfly, which means it likes to live near wet areas like bogs.

These different uses of "Eunomia" show how the idea of order and good management has influenced naming in nature and fiction.

adult_technical.text:
Eunomia is a term with multiple meanings across various fields, including mythology, astronomy, botany, and fiction. In Greek mythology, Eunomia is one of the Horae, goddesses associated with order and justice.

The term "Eunomia" has been adopted in several scientific contexts:

1. **Moths**: It refers to the genus *Eunomia* within the Lepidoptera order.
2. **Asteroids**: Eunomia is the name given to a family of asteroids, with 15 Eunomia being the largest member of this group.
3. **Plants**: In botany, *Eunomia* is a genus belonging to the Brassicaceae family.
4. **Fiction**: In the context of the fictional universe of SoltyRei, Eunomia is a character.

In entomology, the term is also used for specific butterfly species:

- **Callicore eunomia**: A species of nymphalid butterfly.
- **Boloria eunomia** (formerly known as *Proclossiana eunomia eunomia*): This is the scientific name for the bog fritillary butterfly.

These usages highlight the versatility of the term "Eunomia" across different disciplines, each drawing upon the concept of order or well-being inherent in the name.

samples.title: 661 BC

The year 661 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. In the Roman Empire, it was known as year 93 Ab urbe condita . The denomination 661 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events
 Queen Macha of Ireland begins to rule alone, after the death of her husband Cimbaeth.

Births

Deaths

References

Important Events:
- In Ireland, Queen Macha started ruling on her own after her husband, Cimbaeth, died.

Births:

Deaths:
- No notable deaths are recorded for this year.

This year is also known as 661 BC, a name that was first used during the Middle Ages when people began using the Anno Domini (AD) system to date events.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 661 BC, which is before the Julian calendar was introduced, the Roman Empire had its own way of counting years. They called it the "year 93 since the founding of Rome." This year, 661 BC, was named using the Anno Domini (AD) system, which became the standard way to date years in Europe during the Middle Ages.

### Notable Events
- **Queen Macha of Ireland** took over as the sole ruler after her husband, **Cimbaeth**, passed away.

### Births and Deaths
- No specific births or deaths are mentioned for this year.

### References
- This information comes from historical records that were established during the early medieval period.

adult_technical.text:
The year 661 BCE falls within the pre-Julian Roman calendar system. In the context of the Roman Empire, this period is also referred to as the 93rd year from the founding of Rome (Ab urbe condita). The designation "661 BCE" for this year has been consistently employed since the early medieval era, coinciding with the widespread adoption of the Anno Domini (AD) calendar system across Europe for dating purposes.

Historical Events:
In Ireland, Queen Macha commenced her sole reign following the demise of her husband, Cimbaeth.

Notable Births:
No significant births are recorded for this specific year.

Notable Deaths:
No notable deaths are documented for this year.

References:
This entry is based on historical records and the conventional dating system used in ancient and medieval chronology.

samples.title: Holland Township, Kandiyohi County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Holland Township is a township in Kandiyohi County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 369 at the 2000 census.

Holland Township was organized in 1888. A large share of the early settlers being natives of Holland caused the name to be selected.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  of  land and 0.03% is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 369 people, 120 households, and 102 families residing in the township.  The population density was 10.4 people per square mile (4.0/km2).  There were 122 housing units at an average density of 3.5/sq mi (1.3/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.37% White, 0.27% African American, 1.08% from other races, and 0.27% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.08% of the population.

There were 120 households, out of which 47.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 84.2% were married couples living together, and 15.0% were non-families. 11.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 1.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.08 and the average family size was 3.40.

In the township the population was spread out, with 33.9% under the age of 18, 3.8% from 18 to 24, 30.4% from 25 to 44, 22.8% from 45 to 64, and 9.2% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females, there were 105.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 114.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $45,313, and the median income for a family was $46,875. Males had a median income of $30,750 versus $19,107 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,243.  About 7.1% of families and 7.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 7.6% of those under age 18 and none of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Kandiyohi County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: SI derived unit
samples.original_text:
SI derived units are units of measurement derived from the
seven base units specified by the International System of Units (SI). They are either dimensionless or can be expressed as a product of one or more of the base units, possibly scaled by an appropriate power of exponentiation. 

The SI has special names for 22 of these derived units (for example, hertz, the SI unit of measurement of frequency), but the rest merely reflect their derivation: for example, the square metre (m2), the SI derived unit of area; and the kilogram per cubic metre (kg/m3 or kg⋅m−3), the SI derived unit of density. 

The names of SI derived units, when written in full, are always in lowercase. However, the symbols for units named after persons are written with an uppercase initial letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz", but the symbol for metre is "m".

Derived units with special names
The International System of Units assigns special names to 22 derived units, which includes two dimensionless derived units, the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

Examples of derived quantities and units

Other units used with SI
Some other units such as the hour, litre, tonne, bar, and electronvolt are not SI units, but are widely used in conjunction with SI units.

Supplementary units
Until 1995, the SI classified the radian and the steradian as supplementary units, but this designation was abandoned and the units were grouped as derived units.

See also
 International System of Quantities (ISQ)
 International Vocabulary of Metrology
 Metric prefix
 Metric system

References

Bibliography

External links

Derived
 

sv:SI-enhet#Härledda enheter

easy_general.text:
SI derived units are special units of measurement based on the seven basic units in the International System of Units (SI). These derived units can be simple or complex, depending on how they are made from the basic units.

For example, the hertz (Hz) is a derived unit used to measure frequency. Another example is the square meter (m²), which measures area. The kilogram per cubic meter (kg/m³ or kg⋅m⁻³) is a derived unit used to measure density.

When writing out these units, we use lowercase letters. But if a unit is named after a person, like the meter (m), we start the first letter with a capital.

There are 22 special named derived units in the SI system. Two of these are dimensionless, meaning they don't have any physical dimensions. They are the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

Here are some examples of derived units:
- Hertz (Hz): Measures how often something happens each second.
- Square meter (m²): Measures the size of a flat space.
- Kilogram per cubic meter (kg/m³ or kg⋅m⁻³): Measures how heavy something is compared to its size.

Some other units, like hours, liters, and tons, are not part of the SI system but are commonly used with SI units.

Before 1995, the radian and steradian were considered supplementary units. Now, they are just part of the group of derived units.

For more information, you can look up:
- International System of Quantities (ISQ)
- International Vocabulary of Metrology
- Metric prefixes
- Metric system

These resources will help you understand more about units of measurement!

adult_non_technical.text:
SI derived units are special measurement units based on the seven basic units in the International System of Units (SI). These derived units can either be simple or made up of combinations of the basic units, sometimes with scaling factors.

The SI system has given special names to 22 of these derived units. For instance, the hertz measures frequency, while the square meter (m²) measures area. Another example is the kilogram per cubic meter (kg/m³ or kg⋅m⁻³), which measures density.

When writing out the names of SI derived units, they are always in lowercase letters. However, if a unit is named after a person, its symbol starts with a capital letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz," but the symbol for meter is "m."

Some derived units have special names, like the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr), which are used to measure angles and solid angles, respectively.

There are also other units that aren't part of the SI system but are commonly used alongside SI units, such as hours, liters, tonnes, bars, and electronvolts.

Before 1995, the radian and steradian were considered supplementary units, but now they are categorized as derived units.

For more information, you might want to look into the International System of Quantities (ISQ) or the International Vocabulary of Metrology.

adult_technical.text:
SI derived units are units of measurement that are derived from the seven base units defined by the International System of Units (SI). These derived units can be either dimensionless or expressed as a product of one or more base units, potentially scaled by powers of ten. The SI system officially recognizes 22 derived units with specific names, including two dimensionless units: the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

Examples of derived units with special names include the hertz (Hz) for frequency, the square meter (m²) for area, and the kilogram per cubic meter (kg/m³ or kg⋅m⁻³) for density. When written in full, the names of SI derived units are always in lowercase. However, the symbols for units named after individuals begin with an uppercase letter, such as Hz for hertz and m for meter.

In addition to the 22 named derived units, there are numerous other derived units that lack official names and are typically represented using combinations of base units and prefixes. Examples include the joule (J) for energy, which is derived from the base units of kilograms, meters, and seconds (kg⋅m²/s²).

Some non-SI units, such as the hour, liter, tonne, bar, and electronvolt, are commonly used alongside SI units in various contexts. These units, while not part of the SI system, are often employed due to their practicality and widespread usage.

Prior to 1995, the SI system categorized the radian and steradian as supplementary units. However, these units are now considered derived units and are grouped accordingly.

For further reading on related topics, see:

- International System of Quantities (ISQ)
- International Vocabulary of Metrology
- Metric prefix
- Metric system

Additional resources:

- Bibliography
- External links

This revised text maintains the technical accuracy and clarity of the original while enhancing its structure and readability for an adult audience with a technical background in the subject matter.

easy_general.text:
The term "Boston Braves" can refer to several different sports teams:

adult_non_technical.text:

1. **Boston Braves (Baseball)**: This was a baseball team that played in the Major League Baseball (MLB). Now, they're known as the Atlanta Braves. MLB is the highest level of professional baseball in North America.

2. **Boston Braves (NFL)**: This was a football team that played in the National Football League (NFL). They are now called the Washington Commanders. The NFL is the top professional football league in the United States.

adult_technical.text:
The term "Boston Braves" can denote several defunct or rebranded American professional sports teams:

1. **Boston Braves (MLB)**: This refers to the Major League Baseball team that is now known as the Atlanta Braves. The franchise was based in Boston from 1901 to 1952 before relocating to Atlanta.

2. **Boston Braves (NFL)**: This denotes the National Football League team that is now known as the Washington Commanders. The team operated in Boston from 1932 to 1934 before moving to Washington, D.C.

3. **Boston Braves (AHL)**: This is a reference to a former American Hockey League team that existed in Boston during the mid-20th century but has since ceased operations.

4. **Boston Braves (Rugby League)**: This term describes an American National Rugby League team that operated in Boston at some point but no longer exists.

5. **Boston Braves F.C.**: This refers to a Veterans football (soccer) club, indicating a team that likely caters to retired athletes or those with military service experience.

samples.title: Separate-channel signaling
samples.original_text:
Separate-channel signaling is a form of signaling in which the whole or a part of one or more channels in a multichannel system is used to provide for supervisory and control signals for the message traffic channels.  

The same channels, such as frequency bands or time slots, that are used for signaling are not used for message traffic.

See also

 Common-channel signaling

References

Telephony signals

easy_general.text:
Separate-channel signaling is a way to send special messages about phone calls without using the same channels that carry the actual conversations.

In this method, some parts of the communication system are set aside just for sending information like whether a call is busy or if someone has hung up. These special messages help manage the calls but don't mix with the regular conversation.

For example, imagine you have two walkie-talkies. One walkie-talkie is used just to say "call in progress," "call ended," or "line busy." The other walkie-talkie is used to actually talk to someone. This way, the special messages don't get mixed up with the regular conversation.

Common-channel signaling is another type of signaling where all the control and management messages travel through a dedicated channel, separate from the main voice channel.

This helps keep the call management clear and efficient, much like having a dedicated channel for managing walkie-talkie calls.

adult_non_technical.text:
Separate-channel signaling is a method used in communication systems where certain channels are dedicated to sending control and supervisory information, rather than the actual messages or data. Imagine you have a group of phone lines, and some of these lines are used just to tell the system when someone is calling or if there's a problem with the line. These control lines don't carry any voice or data; they're only for managing the system.

This is different from common-channel signaling, where all the control and supervisory information travels on a separate set of dedicated lines.

For example, think of it like having a special lane on a highway just for traffic lights and road signs, instead of mixing them with regular cars and trucks.

In telephony, this kind of signaling helps manage calls and ensures the system works smoothly.

adult_technical.text:
Separate-channel signaling is a method where one or more channels within a multichannel communication system are dedicated to carrying supervisory and control signals for the message traffic channels. These signaling channels operate independently of the message traffic channels, meaning they utilize distinct frequency bands or time slots that are not shared with the data-carrying channels.

In contrast, common-channel signaling involves using a separate, dedicated channel specifically for transmitting signaling information across the network, which is distinct from the channels used for message traffic.

For further reading, see references on telephony signaling.

samples.title: 1440s BC
samples.original_text:
The 1440s BC is a decade which lasted from 1449 BC to 1440 BC.

Events and trends
 1449 BC: Fíachu Labrainne, Milesians' High King of Ireland, is killed and succeeded by Eochu Mumu
 c. 1448 BC: The Gnbtyw people (Genebtyw or Genebtyu) first appear in Ganibatum during the 32nd year of reign of Thutmose III, the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt
1445–1444 BC: The Book of Leviticus is written.
 c. 1440 BC: first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar which controlled the Gulf of İzmir

References

easy_general.text:
The 1440s BC was a time period that lasted from 1449 BC to 1440 BC.

Important Events:
- In 1449 BC, Fíachu Labrainne, who was the leader of Ireland's Milesians, died. He was replaced by Eochu Mumu as the new leader.
- Around 1448 BC, a group called the Gnbtyw (also known as Genebtyw or Genebtyu) appeared in a place called Ganibatum during the 32nd year of the rule of Pharaoh Thutmose III. Thutmose III was the sixth king of Egypt's Eighteenth Dynasty.
- Between 1445 and 1444 BC, a book named "Leviticus" was written.
- Around 1440 BC, the first known city was built near Mount Yamanlar, which was important because it controlled the Gulf of İzmir.

References

adult_non_technical.text:
The period from 1449 BC to 1440 BC is known as the 1440s BC. This was a time when various events and developments took place around the world.

In Ireland, around 1449 BC, a king named Fíachu Labrainne, who was the leader of the Milesians, was killed. He was succeeded by another king called Eochu Mumu.

Around 1448 BC, a group of people known as the Gnbtyw (also sometimes spelled as Genebtyw or Genebtyu) appeared in a region called Ganibatum during the rule of Thutmose III. He was the sixth pharaoh of Egypt's Eighteenth Dynasty, which was a powerful royal family that ruled ancient Egypt.

Between 1445 and 1444 BC, a religious book called the Book of Leviticus was written. This book is part of the Old Testament in the Bible and contains rules and instructions for living according to Jewish law.

Around 1440 BC, the first known city was established on or near Mount Yamanlar. This city controlled the area around the Gulf of İzmir, a large body of water on the coast of modern-day Turkey.

These events give us a glimpse into the history and development of different regions during this time.

adult_technical.text:
The decade spanning 1449 BC to 1440 BC marks significant historical events and developments:

- In 1449 BC, Fíachu Labrainne, the Milesian High King of Ireland, was assassinated and succeeded by Eochu Mumu.
- Around 1448 BC, the Gnbtyw people, also known as Genebtyw or Genebtyu, made their first appearance in Ganibatum during the 32nd year of Thutmose III's reign. Thutmose III was the sixth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt.
- The Book of Leviticus, a key text in the Hebrew Bible, was composed between 1445 and 1444 BC.
- Approximately 1440 BC witnessed the establishment of the first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar, which strategically controlled the Gulf of İzmir.

References

samples.title: Tague, West Virginia
samples.original_text:
Tague is an unincorporated community in Braxton County, West Virginia, United States, along the Right Fork Steer Creek.  The community took its name from nearby Tague Fork creek. A post office was established in Tague in 1911, but was downgraded as an independent rural station of Frametown. It is believed to be the only location in the United States with that name.

References

Unincorporated communities in Braxton County, West Virginia
Unincorporated communities in West Virginia

easy_general.text:
Tague is a small place in Braxton County, West Virginia, U.S., near a river called Right Fork Steer Creek. The town got its name from another nearby stream called Tague Fork.

In 1911, Tague had its own post office. But later, it became part of a bigger area called Frametown and lost its independence. Tague is special because it's the only place in the whole country with this name.

This area is one of many small places in Braxton County and West Virginia that don't have their own city government.

adult_non_technical.text:
Tague is a small community located in Braxton County, West Virginia, United States. It sits near the Right Fork Steer Creek. The town got its name from a nearby creek called Tague Fork.

In 1911, a post office opened in Tague. However, it later became part of a larger rural area called Frametown and lost its independence. Interestingly, Tague might be the only place in the whole United States with this exact name.

This community is just one of many unincorporated areas in Braxton County and across the state of West Virginia. Unincorporated means these places don't have their own government or official status like a city or town does. Instead, they fall under the jurisdiction of a larger area.

adult_technical.text:
Tague is an unincorporated community situated along the Right Fork of Steer Creek in Braxton County, West Virginia, United States. The name of the community is derived from the nearby Tague Fork creek. A post office was established in Tague in 1911, though it was subsequently reclassified as a rural service point of Frametown, losing its independent status. Notably, Tague is believed to be the sole location in the United States bearing this name.

For further reference:
- Unincorporated communities in Braxton County, West Virginia
- Unincorporated communities in West Virginia

samples.title: Pasteur (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
Louis Pasteur (1822–1895) was a French chemist and microbiologist.

Pasteur may also refer to:

Places
 Pasteur Island, an Antarctic island
 Pasteur Peninsula, an Antarctic peninsula
 Pasteur River (Quebec), a tributary of the Aux Rochers River in Quebec, Canada
 Pasteur, a tributary of the Crișul Repede in Oradea, Romania

Astronomical

 Pasteur (Martian crater)
 4804 Pasteur, a main-belt asteroid

Stations

 Pasteur (Paris Métro), France
 Pasteur (Milan Metro), Italy

Other uses
 Pasteur (name)
 Pasteur (film), a 1935 French film starring Sacha Guitry
 MV Pasteur, a coaster that sank in 1971
 SS Pasteur, a French ocean liner launched in 1938
 Pasteur Institute, a French non-profit private foundation
 Pasteur Institute of Iran, a medical research institute
 Musée Pasteur, a museum in Paris, France
 Louis Pasteur University, a former university in Strasbourg, France
 Îlot Pasteur, a building in Monaco

See also 
 List of things named after Louis Pasteur

easy_general.text:
Louis Pasteur (1822–1895) was a French scientist who studied chemistry and tiny living things called microorganisms.

Here are some places named after him:

- **Pasteur Island**: An island in Antarctica.
- **Pasteur Peninsula**: A part of Antarctica.
- **Pasteur River (Quebec)**: A river in Canada that flows into another river.
- **Pasteur River (Oradea)**: A river in Romania that joins another river.
- **Pasteur Street**: A road in Tehran, Iran.

In space:

- **Pasteur (lunar crater)**: A big hole on the moon.
- **Pasteur (Martian crater)**: A big hole on Mars.
- **4804 Pasteur**: A small rock floating in space between Mars and Jupiter.

On trains and buses:

- **Pasteur - AMIA (Buenos Aires Underground)**: A train station in Argentina.
- **Pasteur (Paris Métro)**: A subway station in France.
- **Pasteur (Milan Metro)**: A subway station in Italy.

In movies and ships:

- **Pasteur (film)**: A movie made in 1935 about Pasteur.
- **MV Pasteur**: A boat that sank in 1971.
- **SS Pasteur**: A big ship used to travel across oceans.

Important places and organizations:

- **Pasteur Institute**: A special place in France where scientists do medical research.
- **Pasteur Institute of Iran**: A similar place in Iran.
- **Musée Pasteur**: A museum in Paris, France, that tells stories about Pasteur.
- **Louis Pasteur University**: A school in France that no longer exists.

There are also other things named after him, like:

- **Pasteur effect**: A scientific idea about how sugar changes.
- **Pasteur pipette**: A tool used in science experiments.
- **Pasteur point**: A measure of how much air there is.

These names remind us of his important work and discoveries.

adult_non_technical.text:
Louis Pasteur (1822–1895) was a famous scientist who studied chemistry and tiny living things called microorganisms.

Today, his name is used in many places around the world and space. Here’s how:

**Places Named After Him:**
- **Antarctica:** There's a small island and a peninsula named after him.
- **Canada:** A river in Quebec and a smaller stream in Romania both have "Pasteur" in their names.
- **Iran:** A street in Tehran bears his name.
- **Argentina:** A station on the Buenos Aires subway system.
- **France:** Stations in Paris and Milan.
- **Monaco:** A building named after him.

**Space:**
- **Moon:** A crater on the moon.
- **Mars:** Another crater on Mars.
- **Asteroid:** An asteroid with the number 4804 is named after him.

**Institutions Named After Him:**
- **Research Centers:** The Pasteur Institute in France and its counterpart in Iran.
- **Museum:** A museum dedicated to him in Paris.
- **University:** A former university in Strasbourg, France, was named after him.

**Things Named After Him:**
- **Film:** A movie from 1935 starring Sacha Guitry.
- **Boats:** Two ships, one that sank in 1971 and another ocean liner launched in 1938.
- **Invention:** A special kind of tube used in labs called a Pasteur pipette.
- **Concepts:** The "Pasteur effect," which describes how cells use energy, and the "Pasteur point," which relates to oxygen levels.

These names remind us of his contributions to science and medicine.

adult_technical.text:
Louis Pasteur (1822–1895) was a pioneering French chemist and microbiologist whose work laid foundational principles in the fields of immunology and pasteurization.

The term "Pasteur" is also used in various contexts:

**Geographical Locations**
- **Antarctic**: Pasteur Island and Pasteur Peninsula.
- **Canada**: The Pasteur River, a tributary of the Aux Rochers River in Quebec.
- **Romania**: A tributary of the Crișul Repede in Oradea.
- **Iran**: Pasteur Street in Tehran.

**Astronomy**
- Lunar craters named Pasteur.
- Martian craters named Pasteur.
- Asteroid 4804 Pasteur, located in the main asteroid belt.

**Transportation**
- **Argentina**: The Pasteur station on the Buenos Aires Underground.
- **France**: The Pasteur station on the Paris Métro.
- **Italy**: The Pasteur station on the Milan Metro.

**Names and Media**
- **Film**: "Pasteur," a 1935 French film starring Sacha Guitry.
- **Vessels**: MV Pasteur, a coaster that sank in 1971; SS Pasteur, a French ocean liner launched in 1938.

**Institutions**
- **Research Institutes**: The Pasteur Institute in France, and the Pasteur Institute of Iran.
- **Museum**: Musée Pasteur in Paris.
- **University**: Louis Pasteur University, formerly located in Strasbourg, France.
- **Building**: Îlot Pasteur in Monaco.

**Scientific Concepts**
- **Pasteur Effect**: A phenomenon related to fermentation and respiration.
- **Pasteur Pipette**: A laboratory instrument used for transferring small volumes of liquids.
- **Pasteur Point**: A measure of oxygen levels in tissues.

These diverse usages underscore the enduring legacy of Louis Pasteur's contributions to science and medicine.

samples.title: PKD
samples.original_text:
PKD may stand for:

 Philip Kindred Dick, American science fiction writer
 ICAO PKD, the International Civil Aviation Organization Public Key Directory
 Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia, a movement disorder
 Pi Kappa Delta, a forensics honor society
 Polycystic kidney disease
 PKD1 and PKD2, human genes
 Proliferative kidney disease, caused by the parasite Tetracapsuloides

easy_general.text:
PKD can mean different things:

1. Philip Kindred Dick (PKD) - He was an American writer who wrote stories about science fiction.
2. ICAO PKD - This is part of the International Civil Aviation Organization, which has a Public Key Directory.
3. Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia (PKD) - This is a condition where people have sudden, uncontrollable movements.
4. Pi Kappa Delta (PKD) - It's a group that honors people who do well in public speaking and debate.
5. Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) - This is a health problem where many small cysts grow in the kidneys.
6. PKD1 and PKD2 - These are special parts of our body's cells that help control how our body works.
7. Proliferative Kidney Disease (PKD) - This type of kidney disease happens when a tiny parasite causes problems in the kidneys.

adult_non_technical.text:
Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) can refer to several different things, depending on the context. Here’s what each one means in simple terms:

1. **Philip Kindred Dick**: This is the name of an American writer who wrote lots of stories about science fiction. He imagined worlds very different from our own.

2. **ICAO PKD**: This stands for the International Civil Aviation Organization Public Key Directory. It's like a big list used by airplane companies to make sure they can communicate securely with each other.

3. **Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia**: This is a medical condition where people have sudden, uncontrollable movements when they start moving suddenly. It’s like if you were to jump up and your body started twitching or jerking in ways you can’t control.

4. **Pi Kappa Delta**: This is a special club for students who do well in public speaking and debate. They call themselves a "forensics honor society."

5. **Polycystic Kidney Disease**: This is a health problem where small sacs called cysts grow in the kidneys, making them bigger and causing pain and other health issues.

6. **PKD1 and PKD2**: These are names given to specific genes in humans. Genes are like instructions that tell our bodies how to grow and function. PKD1 and PKD2 are particularly important because they can cause polycystic kidney disease when they don’t work properly.

7. **Proliferative Kidney Disease**: This type of kidney disease happens when a tiny parasite called Tetracapsuloides causes the kidneys to swell and become diseased.

adult_technical.text:
The acronym PKD can denote several distinct entities depending on the context:

1. **Philip Kindred Dick (1928–1982)** - An American science fiction author known for his complex and often dystopian narratives.
2. **ICAO PKD (International Civil Aviation Organization Public Key Directory)** - A component of the ICAO's secure communication infrastructure, facilitating the exchange of cryptographic keys among aviation authorities.
3. **Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia (PKD)** - A neurological disorder characterized by sudden, involuntary movements triggered by voluntary movement or emotional stress.
4. **Pi Kappa Delta (PKD)** - An honor society for forensic sciences, recognizing academic excellence in the field.
5. **Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD)** - A genetic disorder leading to the formation of numerous cysts in the kidneys, impairing their function.
6. **PKD1 and PKD2** - Human genes associated with polycystic kidney disease, specifically the types 1 and 2.
7. **Proliferative Kidney Disease** - A condition caused by the parasitic protozoan *Tetracapsuloides bryosalmonae*, leading to kidney inflammation and damage.

Eagle Point Township is a township in Marshall County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 33 at the 2000 census.

Eagle Point Township was organized in 1890, and named for an eagle's nest in a nearby grove.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  is land and  (1.52%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 33 people, 13 households, and 10 families residing in the township. The population density was 1.2 people per square mile (0.5/km2). There were 18 housing units at an average density of 0.6/sq mi (0.2/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 13 households, out of which 30.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 76.9% were married couples living together, 7.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 15.4% were non-families. 15.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 7.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.54 and the average family size was 2.82.

In the township the population was spread out, with 15.2% under the age of 18, 18.2% from 18 to 24, 30.3% from 25 to 44, 15.2% from 45 to 64, and 21.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 120.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 115.4 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $40,000, and the median income for a family was $45,833. Males had a median income of $22,500 versus $23,750 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,069. There were 20.0% of families and 20.7% of the population living below the poverty line, including 50.0% of under eighteens and none of those over 64.

Townships in Minnesota

Year 834 (DCCCXXXIV) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.

Events 
 By place 
 Europe 
 March 1 – Emperor Louis the Pious is restored as sole ruler of the Frankish Empire. After his re-accession to the throne, his eldest son Lothair I flees to Burgundy.
 Danish Vikings raid the trading settlement of Dorestad (present-day Wijk bij Duurstede), located in the south-east of the province of Utrecht (modern Netherlands).
 Summer – The Viking ship of Oseberg near Tønsberg (modern Norway) is buried in a mound, during the Viking Age (approximate date).
 The first mention is made of the Jona River ('the cold one') in Switzerland (approximate date).

 Britain 
 King Óengus II dies after a 14-year reign. He is succeeded by his nephew Drest IX, as ruler of the Picts.

 By topic 
 Religion 
 July 20 – Ansegisus, Frankish abbot and advisor of former emperor Charlemagne, dies at Fontenelle Abbey in Normandy (or 833).

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 834, which began on a Thursday according to the Julian calendar, several significant events took place across Europe and beyond.

### Events

#### In Europe

- **March 1**: Emperor Louis the Pious, who had previously shared power, was once again the sole ruler of the Frankish Empire. His oldest son, Lothair I, fled to Burgundy after this event.
- **Spring**: Viking raiders attacked Dorestad, a trading town in what is now the Netherlands. This town was located in the southeast part of the province of Utrecht.
- **Late Summer**: A Viking ship from Oseberg, near Tønsberg in modern Norway, was buried in a burial mound during the Viking Age. The exact date is uncertain.
- **Sometime around this period**: The Jona River, known as "the cold one," was first mentioned in Switzerland. Again, the exact date is not precisely known.

samples.title: Bashaw, Wisconsin
samples.original_text:
Bashaw is a town in Washburn County, Wisconsin, United States. The population was 921 at the 2000 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of 33.9 square miles (87.8 km), of which, 33.5 square miles (86.8 km) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.0 km) of it (1.09%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 921 people, 339 households, and 267 families residing in the town.  The population density was 27.5 people per square mile (10.6/km).  There were 387 housing units at an average density of 11.5 per square mile (4.5/km).  The racial makeup of the town was 98.15% White, 0.22% African American, 0.11% Native American, 0.43% Asian, and 1.09% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.43% of the population.

There were 339 households, out of which 34.2% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 73.5% were married couples living together, 3.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.2% were non-families. 17.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 6.8% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.72 and the average family size was 3.10.

In the town, the population was spread out, with 27.1% under the age of 18, 6.5% from 18 to 24, 27.4% from 25 to 44, 25.6% from 45 to 64, and 13.4% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 105.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 106.5 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $43,500, and the median income for a family was $47,014. Males had a median income of $31,923 versus $21,667 for females. The per capita income for the town was $16,982.  About 7.5% of families and 8.8% of the population were below the poverty line, including 10.2% of those under age 18 and 13.7% of those age 65 or over.

References

Towns in Wisconsin

Kapelle is a twin town, which means it has a special friendship with another town. It is twinned with another town, but the name of that town is not mentioned here.

Tell Township is a township in Huntingdon County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 662 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 42.5 square miles (110.2 km), all of it land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 648 people, 238 households, and 179 families residing in the township.  The population density was 15.2 people per square mile (5.9/km).  There were 343 housing units at an average density of 8.1/sq mi (3.1/km).  The racial make-up of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 238 households, out of which 36.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 64.3% were married couples living together, 7.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.4% were non-families. 23.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.70 and the average family size was 3.17.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.9% under the age of 18, 8.8% from 18 to 24, 30.2% from 25 to 44, 21.5% from 45 to 64, and 13.6% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 98.8 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 100.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $32,679, and the median income for a family was $39,444. Males had a median income of $34,444 versus $19,375 for females. About 3.9% of families and 8.5% of the population were below the poverty line, including 13.9% of those under age 18 and 9.0% of those age 65 or over.

easy_general.text:
In the year 554 BC, which is before the Julian calendar was introduced, Rome used a different way to count years. They called it the "year 200 Ab urbe condita," which means "the year 200 since the city of Rome was founded."

This year, 554 BC, was named using the Anno Domini (AD) system, which became popular in Europe during the Middle Ages.

### Events

- **Births:** No notable births are recorded for this year.

samples.original_text:
Year 265 (CCLXV) was a common year starting on Sunday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus (or, less frequently, year 1018 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 265 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Empire 
 Emperor Gallienus tries twice to crush the usurper Postumus, but on the first occasion Aureolus, commander of the elite cavalry, carelessly lets him escape. The second time, Gallienus sustains an arrow wound and has to break off his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus has holed up. He makes no other serious attempt to overcome his rival, instead devoting his attention to the political and military problems in the Danube and eastern parts of the Roman Empire.  
 Postumus makes no move to march on Rome and claim his territory south of Gaul. 
 Gallienus gives the order to fortify Milan and Verona. 
 Gallienus repels the invasion of the Goths in the Balkans. 
 A general of Gallienus' army, Victorinus, defects to Postumus.

 China  
 Sima Zhao, who had been the regent and de facto primary authority of the state of Cao Wei for little over 10 years by this point, passes away, leaving his authority to his eldest son, Sima Yan, who will go on to disestablish the state of Cao Wei in 266, founding the Jin dynasty.

Births 
 Eusebius of Caesarea, Greek historian (approximate date)

Deaths 
 September 6 – Sima Zhao, Chinese general and politician (b. 211)
 Ma Jun, Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot
 Zhu (or Jing), Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 265, which is also written as CCLXV, people started the year on a Sunday. This was during a time called the Julian calendar. Some people also used another way to count years, calling it the 1018th year since Rome was built.

### Events

#### Roman Empire
- **Emperor Gallienus** tried to stop a man named Postumus from being in charge, but failed twice. In one attempt, Gallienus's top soldier let Postumus escape. In the second try, Gallienus got hurt by an arrow and had to stop attacking a city in Gaul. After that, he focused on other problems in his empire.
- Postumus didn't try to take Rome or control the area south of Gaul.
- Gallienus ordered soldiers to build strong defenses in two cities: Milan and Verona.
- Gallienus also stopped an attack by a group called the Goths in a place called the Balkans.
- One of Gallienus's soldiers, named Victorinus, joined Postumus instead.

#### China
- A man named Sima Zhao, who had been in charge of a country called Cao Wei for about 10 years, died. His oldest son, Sima Yan, took over. In 266, Sima Yan changed the name of the country to Jin.

### Births
- A man named Eusebius of Caesarea, who wrote history books, was born around this time.

### Deaths
- **Sima Zhao**, a Chinese general and important leader, died on September 6.
- **Ma Jun**, a Chinese inventor who made a special cart that always pointed south, also died.
- **Zhu (or Jing)**, a queen of a part of China called Eastern Wu, passed away.

This year was very busy with changes in both the Roman Empire and China!

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 265, which is also known as 265 in the Common Era (CE), people were using the Julian calendar, a system that started in ancient Rome. This year began on a Sunday. It was also called the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus, or sometimes the 1018th year since Rome was founded. People have been using the CE dating system since the Middle Ages.

### Events

#### Roman Empire
- **Emperor Gallienus** tried to stop a man named Postumus from ruling, but failed twice. In the first attempt, Gallienus's top soldier let Postumus escape. In the second try, Gallienus got hurt by an arrow and had to stop attacking a town in Gaul where Postumus was hiding. Instead of continuing to fight Postumus, Gallienus focused on other problems in the empire, especially those in the Danube region and the east.
- Postumus didn't try to take over Rome or claim land south of Gaul.
- Gallienus ordered soldiers to build defenses in two cities, Milan and Verona.
- Gallienus defeated a group of invaders called the Goths in the Balkans.
- One of Gallienus's generals, Victorinus, switched sides and joined Postumus.

#### China
- **Sima Zhao**, who had been in charge of the Cao Wei kingdom for about 10 years, died. His oldest son, **Sima Yan**, took over and later in 266, he ended the Cao Wei kingdom and started a new one called the Jin dynasty.

### Births
- **Eusebius of Caesarea**, a Greek historian, was born around this time.

### Deaths
- **Sima Zhao**, a Chinese general and politician, passed away on September 6.
- **Ma Jun**, a Chinese inventor who made a special compass-like device called the south-pointing chariot, died.
- **Zhu (or Jing)**, an empress of the Eastern Wu kingdom, also died.

This year saw significant changes in both the Roman and Chinese empires, marking important transitions in leadership and power.

adult_technical.text:
In the year 265 (CCLXV), a common year beginning on a Sunday according to the Julian calendar, the Roman Empire and China experienced significant events. This year is denoted as 265 AD, reflecting the Anno Domini system that became prevalent in Europe during the early medieval period.

### Events

#### Roman Empire

**Emperor Gallienus** faced challenges against the Gallic usurper **Postumus**. On his first attempt to crush Postumus, Gallienus's elite cavalry commander, **Aureolus**, inadvertently allowed Postumus to escape. In a subsequent campaign, Gallienus sustained an arrow wound and was forced to abandon his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus was entrenched. Rather than pursuing Postumus further, Gallienus redirected his focus to addressing political and military issues in the Danube region and the eastern provinces of the empire.

Postumus did not advance into Italy to claim territories south of Gaul. Instead, Gallienus ordered the fortification of strategic cities such as Milan and Verona. Additionally, Gallienus successfully repelled a Gothic invasion in the Balkans. However, one of his generals, **Victorinus**, defected to support Postumus.

#### China

The regent and de facto ruler of the state of Cao Wei, **Sima Zhao**, passed away after nearly a decade of governance. His eldest son, **Sima Yan**, succeeded him and proceeded to dismantle the Cao Wei state in 266, establishing the Jin dynasty.

### Births

- **Eusebius of Caesarea**: Greek historian (approximate date)

### Deaths

- **Sima Zhao**: Chinese general and politician (born 211)
- **Ma Jun**: Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot
- **Zhu (or Jing)**: Empress of the Eastern Wu state

These events highlight the complex political and military dynamics of the late 3rd century in both the Roman Empire and China.

samples.title: Bedrock Records
samples.original_text:
Bedrock Records is an English record label for trance, progressive house and techno started by Nick Muir and John Digweed. Its name comes from a long running and successful club night held in Hastings and also at Heaven nightclub, London - both also called Bedrock. Bedrock Records has released many singles from artists such as Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars and Jerry Bonham.  Bedrock is also the name that Digweed and Muir use as their production moniker.

Bedrock has had different imprints: Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock and Black (Bedrock). Currently it has Bedrock Digital and one called Lost & Found belonging to Guy J.

The first Bedrock album compiled and mixed by John Digweed was released in 1999, containing several tracks signed to the Bedrock label. 

In 2018, Digweed marked the 20th anniversary of the label with the release of Bedrock XX.

See also 
 List of electronic music record labels

References

External links
Official site

British record labels
Trance record labels
House music record labels
Techno record labels

easy_general.text:
Bedrock Records is an English music company that makes trance, progressive house, and techno music. It was started by two people named Nick Muir and John Digweed. The name "Bedrock" comes from a popular dance party they used to host in Hastings and at a place called Heaven in London.

Bedrock Records has worked with many famous DJs like Astro & Glyde, Steve Lawler, and Guy J. They have released lots of songs under this label. For example, they've worked with artists like Steve Porter, Sahar Z, and The Japanese Popstars.

Bedrock Records has different parts, like Bedrock Breaks and B_Rock. Right now, they have two main parts: Bedrock Digital and Lost & Found, which is owned by Guy J.

In 1999, John Digweed made his first Bedrock album, which included songs from other artists on the label. In 2018, he celebrated 20 years of the label by releasing a special album called Bedrock XX.

If you want to learn more about other music companies that make electronic music, you can look at a list of electronic music record labels.

adult_non_technical.text:
Bedrock Records is an English music company that focuses on trance, progressive house, and techno music. It was founded by two DJs, Nick Muir and John Digweed. The label's name is inspired by a popular club night they ran in Hastings and later at the famous Heaven nightclub in London, both also called Bedrock.

Bedrock Records has worked with many talented artists like Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars, and Jerry Bonham. Not only does the label release singles, but it also uses "Bedrock" as its production name when Digweed and Muir collaborate.

Over the years, Bedrock Records has had different branches, including Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock, and Black (Bedrock). Today, it includes Bedrock Digital and Lost & Found, which is owned by Guy J.

In 1999, John Digweed released the first Bedrock album, which featured a collection of tracks from artists signed to the label. To celebrate 20 years of Bedrock Records, Digweed released "Bedrock XX" in 2018.

If you're interested in learning more about other electronic music labels, you can check out lists of British record labels, trance record labels, house music record labels, and techno record labels. For official information, visit the Bedrock Records website.

adult_technical.text:
Bedrock Records is an English record label specializing in trance, progressive house, and techno, founded by Nick Muir and John Digweed. The label's name is derived from a long-standing and successful club night of the same name, which operated in Hastings and later at the Heaven nightclub in London. Bedrock Records has released numerous singles from prominent artists including Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars, and Jerry Bonham. Notably, Digweed and Muir also use the Bedrock moniker for their production work.

Bedrock Records has maintained various imprints throughout its history, including Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock, and Black (Bedrock). As of the current period, the label operates under two distinct imprints: Bedrock Digital and Lost & Found, the latter being associated with Guy J.

In 1999, John Digweed released the first Bedrock album, a compilation and mix featuring tracks from artists signed to the label. To commemorate the 20th anniversary of the label in 2018, Digweed released "Bedrock XX."

samples.title: Hippomedon
samples.original_text:
Hippomedon (; Ἰππομέδων, gen.: Ἰππομέδοντος) may refer to several figures in Greek mythology:

 Hippomedon, one of the Seven against Thebes.
 Hippomedon, father of Ereuthalion.
Hippomedon, son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe, a defender of Troy killed by Neoptolemus.
Hippomedon, father of Menoites. His son was another defender of Troy and was killed by Teucer.

Notes

References 

 Apollodorus, The Library with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website.
 Quintus Smyrnaeus, The Fall of Troy translated by Way. A. S. Loeb Classical Library Volume 19. London: William Heinemann, 1913. Online version at theio.com
 Quintus Smyrnaeus, The Fall of Troy. Arthur S. Way. London: William Heinemann; New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. 1913. Greek text available at the Perseus Digital Library.

Trojans
People of the Trojan War
Characters in Greek mythology

easy_general.text:
Hippomedon is a name used in Greek mythology for different people. Here are some examples:

1. **Hippomedon**: He was part of a group called the Seven Against Thebes. This group tried to attack the city of Thebes.

2. **Hippomedon**: He was the father of a man named Ereuthalion.

3. **Hippomedon**: He was the son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and a nymph named Ocyrhoe. In the story, he fought on the side of Troy and was killed by a warrior named Neoptolemus.

4. **Hippomedon**: He was also the father of Menoites. His son Menoites also fought for Troy but was killed by another warrior named Teucer.

These stories come from old books about Greek myths. One book is called "The Library" by Apollodorus, written in 1921. Another book is "The Fall of Troy" by Quintus Smyrnaeus, translated by A. S. Way in 1913. These books tell us about the people and events during the Trojan War, which was a big battle between the Greeks and the Trojans.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, there are several characters named Hippomedon, each playing different roles in stories from ancient times. Here’s a simple breakdown:

1. **Hippomedon, One of the Seven Against Thebes**: This Hippomedon was part of a group of seven warriors who tried to attack the city of Thebes. It’s like a team of heroes trying to take over a castle!

2. **Hippomedon, Father of Ereuthalion**: This Hippomedon had a son named Ereuthalion. Think of him as a dad who had a kid.

3. **Hippomedon, Son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and Nymph Ocyrhoe, Defender of Troy**: This Hippomedon was born to Maenalus or Hippasus and a magical being called Ocyrhoe. He fought on the side of Troy during the famous Trojan War, but was eventually killed by a warrior named Neoptolemus. Imagine a brave soldier fighting in a big battle but not making it out alive.

4. **Hippomedon, Father of Menoites**: This Hippomedon also had a son named Menoites. Just like the previous example, he was a parent to a child.

These stories come from ancient texts written by people like Apollodorus and Quintus Smyrnaeus. They describe the lives and adventures of these mythological figures, including their battles and family relationships. These tales help us understand the rich history and culture of ancient Greece.

adult_technical.text:
Hippomedon is a name associated with multiple figures in Greek mythology, each with distinct roles and connections within the narrative of the Trojan War and the broader mythological context.

1. **Hippomedon, One of the Seven Against Thebes**: This Hippomedon is part of the group of seven warriors who besieged Thebes, a significant event in Greek mythology that predates the Trojan War.

2. **Hippomedon, Father of Ereuthalion**: This individual is known for being the progenitor of Ereuthalion, whose identity and fate are not detailed in the provided references.

3. **Hippomedon, Son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and Nymph Ocyrhoe, Defender of Troy**: This Hippomedon is a notable figure in the Trojan War. He is described as a defender of Troy who fell in battle against Neoptolemus, a hero from the Greek side.

4. **Hippomedon, Father of Menoites**: This Hippomedon is also a Trojan warrior, and his son, Menoites, is another defender of Troy who met his end at the hands of Teucer, a Greek archer.

### References

The information about these characters is drawn from classical sources:

- **Apollodorus, The Library**: Translated by Sir James George Frazer, published in 1921. Available online through the Perseus Digital Library, which also provides the original Greek text.
- **Quintus Smyrnaeus, The Fall of Troy**: Translated by A. S. Way, published in 1913. Available online at theio.com and in the Perseus Digital Library, where the Greek text is also accessible.

### Trojans

The term "Trojans" refers to the inhabitants of Troy and their role in the Trojan War, a central conflict in Greek mythology involving the Greeks and the Trojans. Key figures among the Trojans include various warriors and leaders, such as those mentioned above, who played crucial roles in the war's outcome.

This summary provides a structured overview of the different Hippomedons and their significance within the complex web of Greek mythology, particularly focusing on their involvement in the Trojan War.

samples.title: Blackwood National Park
samples.original_text:
Blackwood is a national park in the Charters Towers Region, Queensland, Australia.

Geography 
The park is west of Mount Coolon in North Queensland, 924 km northwest of Brisbane.  It is named after the Australian Blackwood tree species.

The parks is accessible via the Gregory Developmental Road.  Blackwood was created to protect Brigalow Belt plant communities and includes landscapes of rugged hills and gorges, stony ridges and alluvial flats.

About 80 species of birds have been recorded in the park.

Restrictions 
Camping and fires are not permitted within the park.

See also

 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of Queensland
Protected areas established in 1991
North Queensland
1991 establishments in Australia

easy_general.text:
Blackwood is a national park located in the Charters Towers Region of Queensland, Australia.

Geography
Blackwood is about 924 kilometers northwest of Brisbane, which is in the northwestern part of Queensland. The park gets its name from the Blackwood tree, a type of tree found there.

Getting There
You can reach the park using the Gregory Developmental Road. Blackwood was set up to protect certain types of plants and includes areas with rocky hills, deep valleys, rocky ridges, and flat land near rivers.

Wildlife
Over 80 different kinds of birds have been seen in the park.

Rules
You cannot camp or make fires inside the park.

For more information, you might want to look at other protected areas in Queensland.

References
This park is one of the national parks in Queensland. It was created along with other protected areas in 1991. Other new parks were also established in North Queensland and across Australia in 1991.

adult_non_technical.text:
Blackwood is a national park located in the Charters Towers Region of Queensland, Australia. It's situated about 924 kilometers northwest of Brisbane, near Mount Coolon in the northern part of the state. The park takes its name from the Blackwood tree, a native Australian species.

Visitors can reach the park via the Gregory Developmental Road. Blackwood was set up to preserve the Brigalow Belt plant communities, which are unique ecosystems found in this area. The park features a variety of landscapes, including rugged hills, deep gorges, rocky ridges, and flat areas where rivers flow.

Birdwatchers will be pleased to know that over 80 different bird species have been spotted in the park.

There are some rules to follow when you visit. Camping and making campfires are not allowed inside the park to help protect the environment.

For more information on other protected areas in Queensland, you might want to check out the "Protected Areas of Queensland" section. If you're interested in learning about other national parks in Queensland, there’s a list of "National Parks of Queensland." Additionally, you can find details about other protected areas that were established in 1991 under the "Protected Areas Established in 1991" category, or learn about new parks in North Queensland under the "1991 Establishments in Australia" section.

adult_technical.text:
Blackwood National Park is situated in the Charters Towers Region of North Queensland, Australia, approximately 924 km northwest of Brisbane. The park's name derives from the presence of the Australian Blackwood (Acacia melanoxylon) tree species within its boundaries.

Access to the park is facilitated via the Gregory Developmental Road. Established to conserve Brigalow Belt plant communities, Blackwood encompasses a diverse landscape characterized by rugged hills and gorges, stony ridges, and alluvial plains.

Faunal diversity within the park has been documented with the identification of approximately 80 bird species.

Regulations within the park prohibit camping and the use of open fires.

For further information on protected areas in Queensland, refer to the "Protected Areas of Queensland" and "National Parks of Queensland" sections. Additionally, the establishment of Blackwood and other protected areas in North Queensland can be found under "1991 Establishments in Australia."

samples.title: Multiple homing
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, the term multiple homing has the following meanings: 
 telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility so that it can be served by one or several switching centers. Multiple homing may use a single directory number. 
 In telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility to more than one switching center by separate access lines. Separate directory numbers are applicable to each switching center accessed. 

 In military, such as Missiles and loitering munitions, it is ability of a single weapon system or projectile to select, focus and simultaneously engage multiple targets.

See also
 Homing pigeon
 Infrared homing
 Missile guidance

References

Communication circuits
Military terminology

easy_general.text:
In telecommunications, multiple homing means connecting a device to one or more phone centers. This way, if one phone center fails, the device can still work through another center. For example, imagine having two different phone lines to make sure you can always call someone.

In military terms, multiple homing is when a weapon like a missile can target and hit more than one enemy at the same time. It's like a smart arrow that can hit multiple birds in flight.

Here are some related ideas:
- A homing pigeon uses its sense of direction to return home.
- Infrared homing is when a missile follows heat, like a car's engine.
- Missile guidance is how a missile knows where to go to hit its target.

For more information, see:
- How communication circuits work
- Military terms used in weapons

adult_non_technical.text:
In telecommunications, the concept of "multiple homing" refers to how a device, like a phone, can connect to more than one phone company or network. This means if you have a phone, it can be connected to one or several different places where calls are switched around. Sometimes, all these connections might share the same phone number, making it seem like just one line is handling everything.

In simpler terms, imagine your phone can talk to different phone companies at the same time, ensuring your calls stay connected even if one company has issues.

In the military, "multiple homing" describes a weapon's ability to target and hit multiple enemies at once. It’s like a missile that can choose and attack several targets without needing to switch its aim.

For example, a missile can be designed to seek out and destroy multiple enemy vehicles or buildings at the same time, increasing its chances of success in battle.

This idea is also related to "homing pigeons," which use their sense of direction to return to a specific place, and "infrared homing," where missiles lock onto heat signatures to find their targets.

Understanding these concepts helps us see how technology is used in both civilian and military contexts to improve communication and combat effectiveness.

adult_technical.text:
In telecommunications, the concept of multiple homing refers to the configuration of terminal facilities to be served by one or more switching centers. This can involve a single directory number being shared among these switching centers, or distinct directory numbers for each individual connection to a separate switching center via dedicated access lines.

In the context of military applications, particularly with missiles and loitering munitions, multiple homing denotes the capability of a single weapon system to simultaneously detect, engage, and target multiple adversaries. This involves sophisticated sensor and guidance systems that allow the weapon to select and focus on multiple targets.

For further reading, see:

- **Homing Pigeons**: Historical methods of communication using birds.
- **Infrared Homing**: A specific type of missile guidance where the weapon tracks heat signatures.
- **Missile Guidance**: General principles and techniques used to guide missiles to their targets.

References:

- **Communication Circuits**: Detailed technical information on the infrastructure and protocols involved in telecommunications.
- **Military Terminology**: Definitions and usage of terms specific to military operations and equipment.

samples.title: Prado Verde, Texas
samples.original_text:
Prado Verde is a census-designated place (CDP) in El Paso County, Texas, United States. The population is 246 according to the 2010 census. It is part of the El Paso Metropolitan Statistical Area. The ZIP Code encompassing the CDP area is 79932.

Geography
Prado Verde is located at  (31.890005, -106.613181).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 200 people, 60 households, and 55 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,557.7 people per square mile (594.0/km2). There were 62 housing units at an average density of 482.9/sq mi (184.1/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.00% White, 0.50% Native American, and 1.50% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 55.00% of the population.

There were 60 households, out of which 51.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 85.0% were married couples living together, 3.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 8.3% were non-families. 8.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 1.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.33 and the average family size was 3.51.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 35.0% under the age of 18, 6.5% from 18 to 24, 26.5% from 25 to 44, 24.5% from 45 to 64, and 7.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 119.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.0 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $49,286, and the median income for a family was $68,056. Males had a median income of $38,409 versus $45,179 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $14,186. None of the families and 3.9% of the population were living below the poverty line.

References

Census-designated places in El Paso County, Texas
Census-designated places in Texas
